136191862.review:
The highest quality game I have ever played. Multiplayer works very well. High performance even with hundreds of players connected. Players can host headless dedicated servers. Memory injection cheaters that plague other coop games are completely thwarted without using any security nightmare "anticheat" rootkits as the game is fully deterministic. The gui is clean and well thought out for keyboard/mouse. Native linux support. Very good modding support. No DRM so the game, multiplayer, and mods will continue working even if the company behind it goes out of business. The attention to detail is staggering compared to $70 "triple-a" bug infested shovelware that is mainstream these days. I paid 0.016 bitcoin for it back in 2017 worth over $400 now. 100% worth it.

Thank you kovarex and the rest of the team at wube.

First time playing: Make it to maybe the third research pack before your infrastructure totally folds on its self; give up

Second time playing: Make it further, plan better at the start for that third science pack and feel like you can totally handle it when you get there. Unlock the fourth science pack, infrastructure totally folds.... attempt to expand or find a new place to start the new science pack. Get mobbed by alien bugs. Give up. 

Third play through: Start doing math for each of your small modular factories so that they are producing components at the same rate they are consuming them to optimize production. Find out what a main bus is. Get to purple science packs and realize your bus isnt going to be able to supply enough raw plates to meet the needs of the plant. Start trying to optimize conveyors but just make it more fucked up. Give up. 

Fourth play through. Repeat third but learn about trains

Fifth: Finally beat the damn game after 154 hours with a massive base using trains to fulfill your factories insatiable need for iron, copper, coal. Use artillery and rocket spiders to carry out a planet wide extermination campaign against any bug that would dare attack one of your outposts.... Question if you could do this all faster the next time around.

Factorio offers endless entertainment with its deep strategy and immersive gameplay. This is a game that’ll take control over your life! It’s by far the most addictive game I’ve played. Factorio seems highly complex when you first look at screenshots or videos of others’ bases, but it’s not difficult to get into.

It offers an in-game tutorial system with tips about most of the different items, hotkeys, and techniques in the game – as well as a playable tutorial campaign that’s extremely well-made. The tutorial campaign is 10–15 hours of content, and it’s fun and engaging to play, feeling more like a game on its own rather than a tutorial. It’s available for free in the demo, which I recommend playing to see if Factorio is the game for you. Some aspects of the game, such as train mechanics, also offer playable tutorial segments that offer in-depth guidance on that part of the game.

Factorio was inspired by modded Minecraft, particularly the BuildCraft and IndustrialCraft mods. It feels like what a Tekkit modpack for Minecraft would be if it were a game built from the ground-up. The game is extremely polished, with very few bugs and lots of nifty quality-of-life features, as well as a huge modding community offering an endless amount of content, changes, and improvements. However, I recommend playing the game without mods until you’ve reached a point where you feel like you’ve ‘finished’ your first playthrough, except for a few quality of life mods that you may add at any time (although I still recommend playing the game without mods for a while regardless).

The graphics are quite nice for this type of 2D, top-down-view game. The performance 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Factorio offers an enticing gameplay loop where you build machinery and logistics apparatus, upgrade those devices, and optimize your factory. It’s a game all about automation and optimization, where you constantly strive to produce everything as quickly and efficiently as possible. The game offers an enticing research paths with unlocks and bonuses that constantly leaves you excited for what’s next. This is a game that’s hard to put down! While the game is [i]never[/i] on sale, it’s hard to deny that the game is undoubtedly worth the 32 €/$35. This is one of those games that you’ll get hundreds upon hundreds of hours out of – if not [i]thousands[/i]!

131337595.review:
Just a heads-up - I bought this game way back when it was still in very early development (think Desura and Humble Bundle when it was actually good), so no, I didn't just play this game for 3 hours that are logged on Steam.

This negative review isn't to say the game is bad. [b]If you're interested in playing the game and are capable of buying it - do so[/b]. It's a very good "factory" game (and somewhat brought this genre to the masses), very customisable and has Steam Workshop support, which is always a big plus.

However, I do have to point out the reason this review is negative. I won't go too deep into detail, but it's simply that Wube (developers of this game) promised to not increase the game's price and to not put it up on any sales, basically the Nintendo approach (which is actually not that good, but I digress). However this week they decided to "adjust the price for inflation since the release in 2016". 
To their credit, the increase by 5$ is indeed approximately correct; however they didn't take several things into account. Their game isn't getting any newer, there is an expansion promised that nobody knows the release date of; other than that the game has been pretty much the same since full release in 2020, apart from minor bugfixes. Which begs the question, does Wube think that their game is not only worth the same price, but even more now? If anything, considering their celebration of selling over 3 million copies back in February 2022 - you wouldn't think they'd need even more money. 
3 million copies for 20$ each (average of all regional currencies) is 60 mil before Steam cut, 42 mil after the cut (we're also assuming they didn't get any better percentage than 30% which simply isn't the truth). 42 mil $ for (at the time of 3 mil copies) 7 years, not including any money from Kickstarter and sales before they went on Steam. 6 mil $ per year, assuming they spend around 1 mil $ on any expense besides salaries - that's 5 mil $ per year for a team of 30, or ~14k $ per person per month. According to public sources that's on the lower end of average Software Dev salary (keep in mind Software Dev isn't fully equal to Game Dev).

It's less so the problem of: "Oh no, they're increasing the price". And more a problem of: "Oh no, they lied to us about not increasing the price and justify it with bullcrap". There's no legit reason to use the Nintendo scheme, it's dumb at the core and considers digital media to always cost the same, despite obviously lagging in comparative quality over time. Shoutout to Kovarex, one of the Wube devs, who doubled down on these statements and made a fool of himself on Reddit.

[i]Small update for the price increase aftermath:[/i]
I genuinely can't begin to comprehend how Wube decided to not only ignore the backlash, but also make it worse by completely destroying regional prices. 
There's a whole discussion to be had about issues with Valve's recent changes to suggested regional pricing and the misinformation that's been spread about it (e.g. "the pricing is enforced by Valve").
What is factual, however, is that a lot of "factory" and resource management games on Steam have much better regional pricing than Factorio.

Satisfactory (30$), The Planet Crafter (20$), Mindustry (10$), RimWorld (35$), Volcanoids (20$), Dyson Sphere Program (20$), Oxygen Not Included (25$) all have 31-33 regional prices that are below recommended by Valve, with a median of 30-40% price decrease. Factorio has 12 regional prices below recommended by Valve, with a whopping median of 5-6% price decrease (all of the above info publicly available on SteamDB). What the hell, Wube?
Furthermore, I want to point out that RimWorld, despite having the same $ price, is on sale often, with 2 recent sales being 28$. RimWorld is also special, because it started in 2013 on Kickstarter and released on Steam in Early Access in 2016 just like Factorio. Yes, Rimworld has DLCs, but 2 of the 3 have recently gone on sale, they also cost less than the base game (unlike what Wube promises with their upcoming expansion).

If you're interested in Factorio, but the price is too steep (especially regional) for you - I recommend looking into Satisfactory, Mindustry and Dyson Sphere Program. If you're more interested in resource management - look into other games I've mentioned (also Dwarf Fortress).
All of the games I've mentioned go on sales, obviously have good regional pricing and the very few that increased their price after release - increased it because of added content, not because of inflation.

"Thanks, this is appriciated. Big part of it is, that our (or at least mine) approach to money is, that once you have enough to live comfortably, and enough to financially support the ongoing (and future) projects you want to do, you don't really need more. The factory must grow."

138722152.review:
Oh boy, where do I even begin with Factorio? This game has taken me on an emotional rollercoaster that rivals any real-life rollercoaster, complete with moments of exhilarating joy and heart-wrenching frustration. It's like having a pet tiger—utterly fascinating, yet occasionally ready to rip your face off.

Let's start with the joy. Factorio is a captivating game that hooks you from the moment you crash land on an alien planet. The sheer satisfaction of starting with a few mining drills and eventually building a sprawling factory empire is indescribable. The sense of accomplishment as you optimize your production lines and automate everything in sight is like eating a perfectly cooked steak while your favorite song plays in the background.

But oh, dear player, beware! Factorio's difficulty is as real as the feeling you get when you step on a LEGO brick barefoot. It lulls you into a false sense of security before slapping you in the face with a smorgasbord of challenges. Your dreams of constructing a flawless, spaghetti-free factory will soon be replaced with a tangled mess of belts, pipes, and tears.

You see, Factorio has a twisted sense of humor. Just when you think you've got it all figured out, it throws a wrench (or a dozen) into your well-oiled machine. Alien biters will invade your precious factory, sending you into a panic reminiscent of a cat chasing a laser pointer. And don't even get me started on the power struggles—trying to balance your energy grid is like juggling flaming chainsaws while riding a unicycle on a tightrope.

The frustration is real, my friend. It's the kind of frustration that makes you question your life choices and contemplate adopting a simpler existence as a hermit in the woods. But just when you're about to rage-quit and sell your soul to the nearest pawnshop, you'll have a breakthrough. A solution will materialize in your tired brain, and suddenly, your factory will hum with efficiency once again. It's a sweet victory that makes all the hair-pulling moments worthwhile.

Factorio is a game that delights in both your success and your suffering. It will simultaneously make you feel like a genius and an imbecile. But through it all, you'll be captivated by its addictive gameplay and the promise of creating the ultimate automated utopia. You'll laugh, you'll cry, and you'll probably swear like a drunken pirate.

So, my fellow brave factory builders, I wholeheartedly recommend Factorio. Embrace the joy, embrace the pain, and remember that deep down, it's all part of the beautifully chaotic journey that is this game. Happy engineering, and may your factories be forever spaghetti-free!

Rating: ★★★★☆

128279091.review:
Getting 100% was quite fun, satisfying.

approximate amount of time to 100%: 100-200h
Estimated achievement difficulty: 8/10
Minimum number of playthroughs needed: 1
Multiplayer achievements: No. (but you can get achievements in multiplayer)
Missable achievements: No.
Grinding Achievements: Yes. Both production/minute and total production of certain parts... 20M green circuits being the worst.
DLC-Only achievements: No.
Time-gated achievements: No.
Speed-run achievements: Yes, Launch rocket in 8h most notable
RNG-achievements: No.
Does difficulty affect achievements: No (you can make a super-easy map).
Unobtainable/glitched achievements: No.

The game is the progenitor of a genre of games. It's simply awesome to this day.
Achievements are overall dependent on having an efficient factory but can be "cheesed" by making a flat map with no polution and semi-peacefull biters (the options that disable achievements are clearly labeled)

The internet is full of guides and videos. And you can even import and auto-build entrie bases... they can get most of the achievements for you

The game has an internal achievement tracker and I want to say that's simply really good QOL.

----

Lastly i'll note about 2 subjects that came up with this game:
*  The developers tend to get into politics ... taking sides on social issues. I find it quite annoying to be preached at by my escapism  ~NO MATTER IF I AGREE WITH THEM OR NOT~ .
*  The price is fixed and doesn't ever go on sale ( from 5E to 40E depends on where you live on the globe but averages to 30Euro/$). And while I agree with the devs that sales usually ensure you buy games that are never played due to FOMO I must say that the game (in my opinion) might not be "worth all the money". And that's something that sales do help with... for some players this games is worth 60$ and for some it may be worth 15$... and with this I feel that choice is now removed from the player.

Edit: 400~ hours in ..game's still fun. Mod support is done through the game itself... The community is creative. Can't wait for the Expansion.

145831502.review:
I have a friend who loves this game. I was going to delete it out of my library because someone bought it for me way back in Early Access years ago, we played it for all of 40 minutes and never again. It had just been sitting in my library, collecting dust and cobwebs but the friend who loves this game convinced me to give it a go once more and dive into the world of automation and sprawling factory landscapes. 

It's definitely not my wheelhouse but with his help I'm learning it to be. It is pretty straightforward if you know what to look for otherwise it can be frustrating. The game just gives you tools and expects you to figure it out yourself. Which is great if you are familiar with this genre. But seeing as I'm a lowly scrub super out of touch with games like this... yeah. Frustrations abound! Lots of moving parts and calculations and keeping track of it and holding solid in that mindset is the essence of this game and considering I excel at that type of thing in other areas of gaming and life you'd think I'd've taken to this like a fish in a rocket but alas! It's presented in a different way than I'm used to and rewiring my thinking it's kinda part of the fun. :)

So a big thanks the friend shape for telling me to keep this. It may make me want to drive off a bridge sometimes but I'm getting the hang of it! Sometimes a really good game is one that snakes around your brain like conveyor belt connections, leaving a modular shifting emotional spectrum in its wake.

131460088.review: I am a 58 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son downloaded Factorio and in less than a week, he had already played for over 11 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

139804152.review:
The game is called Cracktorio for a reason. I'm just going to do this one last thing before I go to bed at 11:00 an all of a sudden it's 4:00am and I have to be awake for work soon... It's just so addicting. The vanilla version will keep you busy for a while but there are mods that can take over 1000 hours to complete. Start unmodded, or you'll most likely be overwhelmed with the amount of content. 

Play. The. Tutorial. 

Yes, the graphics aren't the most modern/flashy, but it doesn't matter. You look past that once you get to the problem solving the games requires. Don't look up the best way to do things, the fun in the game is figuring out what works for you. Maybe on another play through look and see how others did things.

Overall 10/10 for the game. 1/10 for game/life balance -- you just keep finding yourself thinking about how you're going to solve your next resource problem throughout the day. Then you'll understand the phrase:

The factory must grow.

132263194.review:
Greatest automation game of all time. The base game is absolutely fantastic. If you're into mods then you'll be playing this still when you're 395 years old. In all honesty I like rating a game on price vs entertainment value and a strong indicator is time spent playing. If I spent this time at the movies I'd pay over £1,600 for an inferior product, it's really a no brainer. This game is a steal and I know over the years I'll spend hundreds of hours more in this. As people say "The factory must grow" and you'll be stuck in dopamine heaven with a mental list so long you'll always be thinking "I'll just do that next task" as you look at the clock and realise it's not 10pm, it's 5am. 

This game does almost everything right and is a masterclass in game design followed by a near flawless implementation. After a few hundred hours in you'll have a good sense of what's what, but you'll always have a new bigger factory with a better layout in mind that you'll want to try. It's not arbitrarily punishing in any of the standard ways, and in fact it's only your personal standards that will cause you issues. This game has set a bar so high, all other imitators, whatever their USP have failed to come close to it. The community is absolutely ironclad as well, clearly enjoying the benefits of a game that had community in mind from the outset. 15/10 can't recommend enough.

124902689.review:
[h1] This is part one of three reviews [/h1]

 I have wanted to review what i think are the big three factory/automation games for a while now. Those being [b]Factorio, Dyson Sphere Program, and Satisfactory[/b]. I have them listed in the order I'm reviewing them, as well as the order of their quality to me.

 I think this review should serve to illustrate the quality of Factorio, and what makes it special when compared even to the factory games that have now released in it's wake. There is no question that Factorio is a masterpiece, but what sets it atop the tower? Why do I think that other automation games are struggling to live up to Factorios legacy? I hope that is something I can answer.

[h1] Performance [/h1]

 The common theme that you will quickly pick up on in this review is that Factorio continues to set the standard for the genre it takes place in, and it's performance is no different. Factorios graphics are not cutting edge, fully realized 3D environments like Satisfactory, or fully modeled planetary systems like Dyson Sphere, but Factorios pixel art is highly detailed, and beautiful to look at, from both a micro and a macro level. Everything flows so beautifully, in close to 1k hours in this game, I have never had my game drop below 60FPS. My brother who actually has the income to get a 144Hz monitor, speaks to the same level of consistent performance even at that elevated framerate. The game is fully capable of handling thousands of things on the screen, be they enemies, items in your factories, or friendly bots and trains running effortlessly at your chosen framerate.

[b]tl;dr: Factorio's performance is as close to perfect as you can get, with large selection of options to tweak and configure. (I mean they got this running native on the Switch)[/b]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

 Factorio is a top down game, and the gameplay consists of resource gathering > resource automation > resource refining > logistics > enemies/expansion > back to step one. Every element of Factorio's design is so immaculately crafted, and balanced from years of early access development, and careful attention to feedback from the community. It feels that you always have a goal, you always have something you could do, something you need to do, or some system you could be doing better or all together not even engaging with. Every system added to the gameplay loop feels so intentional, and so deliberate to push you forward. Your goal is to get a satellite into space, which requires the refinement of materials, the problem is that the locals don't particularly care for the pollution your machines produce, and as the pollution reaches them, they will attack you. They will also begin to mutate, and become stronger, so enemy progression is intrinsically tied to your progression as well. Factorio also includes an insanely comprehensive and easy to use blueprint system, that allows you to effortlessly copy the design of something and paste it somewhere else, even in different saves, later in the game with construction bots you can even have these blueprints completely built for you automatically. You can also save these blueprints and share them with the community, or use some that the community have put together. It is a wonderful system that the other factory games are still catching up with, and is just another perfectly designed element to continuously push you towards progression.

 Factorio is as much about logistics as it is about automation, and once again Factorio sets the gold standard in its genre in this category as well. You have belts for short-medium range transport, trains for long distance hauls, logistic robots that can fulfill requests and keep you and your base supplied, and even a Turing-complete logic system if you want to get into the computational aspects of your base. All of these elements are masterfully crafted, and feel so well designed, so well thought out. These are not just systems that were tacked on, but fully realized and in depth mechanics that you can chose to engage or not engage with at your leisure.

 Factorio is completely customizable as well! Don't want enemies? turn them off. Do you want enemies but don't want them to expand at all? disable it. Want resources to be close to infinite and huge? do it. The game has mod support built directly into it, no steam workshop required. You download all mods straight through your main menu, and the game is good to go. The community has created some amazing mods that include entire additional mechanics, total overhauls, sprite reworks etc. 


[b]tl;dr: Factorio's gameplay once again sets the standard for gameplay, with clever and fully realized systems including full logistics, psuedo tower defense gameplay, built in mod support, generous blueprint system, multiplayer and a Turing-complete logic system that masterfully always pushes you towards your next goal[/b]

[h1] Overall tl;dr: [/h1]

[b] Factorio is one of the best games I have ever played, and its hard to put into words how much i recommend this game, and I do not think that is a failure of my writing ability, but rather a testimate to how masterfully this game is designed. From its insanely impressive and consistent performance, to its incredible depth and variety in its systems, Factorio (and its eventual expansions) is something i cannot recommend enough. Sure it is not for everyone, if you didn't like playing modded minecraft when you were younger, you probably won't enjoy this, and thats okay; but if you found even the slightest bit of fun in that gameplay loop, you will find something to love in this game[/b]

This is quite an amazing game, though I am still in the early part of the game, even after 30+ hours. So, it is expensive, when compared to other factory games which Factorio has since inspired, BUT....

And while it only shows the early game technologies, there's a whole lot of game that can be done with just the first two science levels.

And my second point is that the price includes access to all the community mods and all the developer updates. I bought it on the developer's website, so I could get access to their forum. Maybe purchasing from Steam provides that too, but it's something to consider. Anyway, the thirty-five dollar purchase will give you a lifetime of automation gaming, if that's your thing. Works great with my gnu-linux desktop and my spouse's window laptop. We had no problems getting the game running over the network. Also the game's discord server and website wiki were super helpful resources.

131235142.review:
If you're at all familiar with Factorio, you probably already know that the game doesn't go on sale. Literally, it does not ever go on sale. The justification for this given by the developer is that the game is just so well-loved that it doesn't make sense to put it on sale; the sheer amount of goodwill the community has for the game means a sale isn't necessary. I've always thought that this explanation was flimsy, but at least acceptable to ignore, if not actually agree with. But now, after six years of being released and going on three years since the last update, the developers have decided to increase the price of the game to account for inflation. I want to be clear that if this game had released at $35 with the content it has today, I would have defended it as being worth the cost. However, I think that the developers conveniently ignoring the fact that video games generally depreciate in value over time (which would then balance out any price increase due to inflation), as well as the fact that they have never put the game on sale, just strikes me as legitimately greedy. There was no reason for this; they have millions and millions of dollars in sales; the extra $5 does nothing but spite players who haven't played this game but have been desperately hoping they could get it on sale some day. 

It just comes across as silly and greedy, especially when the devs have previously stated that the DLC they plan to release will cost the same as the base game. So will it cost the original $30, or is this a cheap way to raise the price of the DLC as well so they get an extra $5 from every existing player that buys it?

Also, final note. Increasing price for inflation is just stupid. When games raise their price, it's because they have added content. I literally cannot think of another game that has done this the way Factorio is doing it. AAA games are releasing at $70 now, but they release at that price, they don't raise it mid life cycle, and especially not 3 years after the last major content was added.

This is a game that I love from a developer that I now cannot recommend buying from.

131258045.review:
The game starts with you crash landing on a planet, slowly build up a factory by gaining resources, first by digging them up yourself then eventually making machines to do it for you.  You then build factories to build better and more complicated products until you have basically a self sustaining factory that builds exactly what you need, which is basically parts for a spaceship. There is quite a bit of up front work for hours but eventually you end up with a factory that runs itself.  The spaceship parts keep flowing and the people in space are really happy with your work.

After awhile though, you spend less and less time improving the factory until it basically just runs on its own.  Sure, you might stop in once in 2-3 years to add new things like a walking spider robot to ensure that you keep those space people happy.  But after awhile it gets a little stale and you have to promise those space people you’ll make more stuff to send them, but it will take awhile.

Then one day you realize that an inflation crisis is affecting the world and its a perfect excuse to charge the space people more money for the same product you’ve been giving them for 3 years straight so you can afford a better cappuccino machine on your yacht.  Who cares that the factory runs itself, hasn’t been affected at all by inflation and you haven’t upgraded it in decades.  You are happy to charge people more for the same space slop you are feeding the space people, even though you promised you would never do it.  Then you pat yourself on the back and go back to oppressing the locals.  That’s basically how the game ends.

All in all, the game is fun but for some reason it leaves a bad taste in my mouth every time I log in.

I give it 2/10.  A little to close to real life for my taste.

141056477.review:
TL;DR, Factorio's regional price in Argentina increased from 400 ARS to 2500 ARS in a single day, presumibly to deter people in the US (or any other country) using a VPN to buy it cheaper here. It's still way cheaper here, so people will keep doing that, and the people that actually buy it in Argentina still have to pay a (roughly) 75% tax on top of it, so really it's only fucking us over.

Non-TL;DR:
Factorio is an absolutely great game, I love it.
So I'm a bit sad to leave a negative review. It's about regional prices. I live in Argentina, and the recent-ish regional price increases are ridiculous.
Last year, I bought this game for myself and a friend of mine, at 330 Argentine Pesos for each copy. Later it increased to 400 ARS, which is still fine.
 This year I wanted to buy it for someone else, only to find that the price went up from 440 ARS to 2500 ARS, roughly a 560% price increase. This is absolutely horrid keeping in mind that on top of that, over here we have to pay a huge additional tax on top of that, which ends up leaving the game priced at 4375 ARS.

These regional prices are meant to stop people using a VPN and buying the game in our currency from overseas, but these changes aren't actually going to stop that. It's still way cheaper for almost anyone to buy it here with a VPN, since they don't have dumb taxes on top of that, so sure, you're slightly deterring those people, but ultimately you're just massively fucking over people in Argentina. I don't expect many people that *actually live here* to buy this game anymore.

Most of the negative reviews based on pricing are complaining about the developers raising the price over time. It's true that it's a questionable practise, but I personally don't view it as that huge of a problem. You could at least argue in favour of it, with the developers actively working on the game and adding/fixing stuff over the years.
Raising the regional price by over five times overnight, however... That's a problem.

If you're from Argentina, I guess just pirate the game until our crumbling economy's inflation devalues our monopoly money enough that this game is actually worth buying again.

132047187.review:
Is the game worth $35 to me? Yes.
Is it fair to raise price from $30 to $35? No.

If correct price of a product is what people are willing to pay then it is worth different amounts to different people.

If the correct price of a product is what it costs to make it, then it is $0 to make another copy of a digital game. Obviously there are development costs incurred upfront by the studio, but that's been long paid for many times over.

Inflation makes sense for physical products that cost ingredients, salaries, and transportation to make and deliver to the consumer. For a digital game, it does not make sense.

They just wanted a big sales boost that come with traditional discounts that other games offer, so instead they announced an upcoming price increase to rush people into buying it early. They may have been successful in the short term, but alienated a bunch of their fans like me.

This is probably the first and only review of a game I'll ever bother to write. The factory must grow.

128586904.review:
I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Factorio and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

(Real btw, definitely not a meme)

129932266.review:
I think it would be fair to say that I have not been a great person most of my life. After growing up in a highly dysfunctional environment, I quickly became addicted to a variety of drugs, moving onto other drugs when those old drugs became 'boring', so to say. From 14 years old I was drinking alcohol, smoking weed, and taking Xanax before eventually moving onto harder drugs like cocaine, methamphetamine and heroin at around 15 years old. My persistent drug habit caused me to drop out of school at the age of 16, and from that point, I had no skills to find a job and no role model who could guide me along the right path. My drug usage only skyrocketed, and drugs cost money, which caused me to unwisely steal a large amount from my mother and father. They did not deserve such treatment, as they only tried their best, despite their own problems. 

I was subsequently evicted, and left on the streets of London to fend for myself. I would wander aimlessly, filing job applications to any place I could, just to afford my drug habit, only to be given a dirty look as if I'm some kind of scum for even trying. Each time I would be told, "well I guess we'll call you back, what's your number?", which I understand is a platitude, but I could not even afford a phone to even play into this and give a phone number. I would forage for food in garbage cans and the woods, as I could not even bring up the change to afford a stick of gum.

Then, on one cold night in November, I overdosed on some oxycodone, which ended up containing fentanyl. Thankfully, a friend administered some narcan and saved my life. Eventually, an ambulance showed up and I was ushered into the back of it. In that moment, at now 21 years old, I thought to myself, what the hell is my life? I have wasted so much of my time, youth and potential, so many memories, achievements and experiences I could have had, just chasing drugs. Why? I broke down. I knew things had to change, I knew there was something better than this waiting for me out there.

I went into rehab shortly afterwards. Recovery was long, but there are some amazing people out there, who are quite frankly not paid enough, that patiently and selflessly provided me the support to get better. They helped me quit drugs, discuss my problems in therapy, find a job, find housing, and pursue a better life. I rekindled the relationship that I destroyed with my parents, and found a social circle who supported me. I was just starting to discover just how wrong I was about the world and how great life can be without drugs. 

Then I started playing this fucking game.
10/10 would recommend.

---

Freely save, die as much as you want but protecting yourself from aliens isn't so hard but protecting your ever expanding megabase is kinda of game. 90% of my deaths were to me crossing the road but my automated fast-as-fuk-boiiii trains yeeting me into an isekai anime.

kind of game

123550872.review:
It's hard to review Factorio, cause I doubt you have any doubts about it. It's a factory building game, the best of all time. 

The thing is, [b]there is literally nothing else but a factory game there.[/b]

[h1]if you are interested in this game, YOU'LL LIKE IT.[/h1] It's that simple. I can't think of a SINGLE flaw in this game. It's addicting, well made, realistic, and truly tests your cognitive abilities. Even the enemy system is just to serve the factory building elements.

[h1]This game has almost endless content.[/h1]
There is just SO much to do. It'd take THOUSANDS, AND THOUSANDS OF HOURS to truly be satisfied with JUST THE MAIN GAME. There are SO many ways to design your base, SO many ways to make it more efficient, SO many ways to eliminate your enemies, SO many ways to rethink your process. And this is just in the base game, which leads on to the next point.

[h1]The mods.[/h1]

Factorio, is very, very, very mod friendly. It literally comes with a mod browser in the main menu. And the mods themselves are just SO good. Krastorio 2 is such a good beginner mod pack, that I'd say almost tipples the main games content, which in the end gives 10x the stuff to do if you want to redesign your factories. I beat this mod a few months back. Currently I'm doing a run with my friend of Space Exploration, a mod that takes over 200 hours on average, that literally adds solar system exploring to the game, and adds so much to the point of it feeling like truly infinite possibilities can be achieved.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
Factorio's multiplayer is probably its weakest element. And that's not due to its balancing or anything. Factorio's multiplayer is VERY good. It's unbelievably easy to connect to your friends, there's literally an option in the multiplayer menu to sort by friends. Joining a world will ask for a password and everything, but it also will [b]sync your mods for you.[/b]

Overall, this is genuinely a fantastic game, absolutely would recommend to anyone interested.

123474288.review:
[h1]Factorio[/h1]

[b]Overview:[/b]
 Ahem, pathetic human, listen to me! If you're seeking a game that will consume your existence and make you forget about your meager existence, then let me introduce you to Factorio. This game is like Cybertronian energy to your circuitry.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
You begin with a puny factory, thinking you can control it with ease. But before you know it, you're submerged in conveyor belts and nuclear reactors, and you won't even know what day it is. Who cares about the graphics when you're constructing your own empire?

[b]Sound:[/b]
The sound effects will excite your audio receptors, and you'll be absorbed in the clanking and humming of machinery. You won't even realize that you've played through the night until your friends, Ramjet, Thrust, and Skywarp, ping you to ask if you're still alive.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Factorio is a game that will rule your life, and you won't even know it. But, who needs a life when you can become the ruler of your little virtual world? I highly suggest this game to all Decepticons, just don't blame me when you forget to fuel up and recharge for a week straight. I give this game a Starscream 10/10.

135501552.review:
I've had this game in my library for years and haven't really touched it.  I typically have trouble getting into crafting and survival games, but something about Factorio has really captivated me.  At it's core, the game is very simple - gather some resources, construct belts, inserters, machines etc.  Everything you build in Factorio can be used to construct an elaborate, automated factory to build... more factory.  Ultimately, the main goal is to launch a rocket by researching and building advanced technology.  Looking through the research evolution tree, this seems like such a daunting task at first, but once you get going, your time with this game will fly and before you know it, you're launching that first rocket.  Playing with friends is also a blast, and I've had a lot of fun playing with my son.  There are some optional tower defense elements to this game which can make things a little more interesting by needing to set up walls, turrets and defending your base.  You can also play a more offensive role, by building tanks and the amazing Spidertron and patrolling to clear out the nearby hives that might be smelling your pollution.

I highly recommend this game and it is one of the few that I could play and play and not get bored with.  I'm over 100 hrs in and still have not touched any of the various mods (which I know there are several really cool ones) from the community.  Very well made game and you can tell the developers put a lot of love into Factorio.  Easy 10/10 for me.

141334430.review:
I love this game so much. If you aren't careful this game will consume you though.
The game starts fairly simple. You crash land on an alien planet with hostile natives. Your goal is to build a rocket to escape, you'll need to build up the infrastructure to do so first though.

There is always something to do. You'll need to automate production of materials for science. While you're at it why not automate things you use often? Just a slight problem, the game does not tell you the direct ratios for things, and normally things do not split cleanly. You make things perfect, not at first, and that is the best part. By fixing issues and making your life easier through automation you are setting up a whole host of problems that future you will discover, troubleshoot, and fix.

The factory must grow.

Playing the game makes more game for you to play in this sense. Time will fly if you aren't careful. You'll be consumed by the "just one mores."

To add on, the game is reasonably priced, and even a very long time ago in early access this game felt like more of a full game than many modern games.

The modding scene is rich, there is a mod browser and manager baked right into the game. It is great, there are many complete overhaul mods and qol mods if vanilla eventually gets bland for you.

There are also tons and tonss of game settings you can tweak before starting to mix things up a bit. Everything from world generation settings to enemy evolution settings. It is great.

The game runs well, plays well, isn't a buggy mess, and is priced well. Kind of a rare sight.

The factory must grow.

I'd recommend trying not to spoil much for yourself before you try to play, your first play through will likely be the messiest. You have so much to learn, and that is so much of the fun. Don't get me wrong replayability is great, but nothing is quite like your first time learning the systems and creating speget.

Don't be afraid to use the in game tutorials if you get stuck though! They do a great job. They are always available in the top right of your screen, even mid game. They allow you to play around a little bit to figuring things out with no strings attached.

The factory must grow.

If you're waiting for a sale they have stated long time ago they have no plans to do sales. I haven't ever seen one either.

Buy it, give it a go. If it isn't for you refund it. Factorio isn't for everyone. It is a dangerous drug for those it is though.

The factory must grow.

141949472.review:
Such a mind-boggling experience to have.

Factorio starts off with such a simple premise which reels you in by the hook and then only after 5 hours have you noticed that you just barely scraped the surface of what the game has presented before you. It will drag you into such a rabbit hole that you'll start to question yourself if it's better to go deeper or to finally climb out. Only then will you realise that hours have gone by as you've expanded your starter base into a location of operation which outputs many products to construct bigger projects.

From mining, power management, inventory management, alien invasions, refining resources, discovering new technologies, weapons, environmental changes, pollution, transportation and finally rockets.

The game starts off with simply mining for scraps of iron and before you know it, you've started creating computer circuits which are needed to be used by other components to be combined into something bigger. You repeat this process until you have your desired outcome and then proceed to research the next technology in the tree.

This is the main driving force of Factorio, unlocking new things to mess around with in order to progress and try to create a sustainable and efficient factory in order to launch a rocket to space whilst trying to reduce pollution caused by your machines in order to fend off local invading aliens that try to shut down your operations.

A solo experience is a charm but a co-op experience is a treat. Being able to divide tasks between friends really increases your productivity and makes the game that much more enjoyable. One person can take care of the aliens whilst the other focuses their efforts on reinforcing the base with turrets or rockets.

A one of a kind game that really is unique.

8.5/10

123894397.review:
If you haven't heard of this already, chances are, this review won't do anything to change your mind.
If you HAVE heard of this, and haven't bought it (or tried the demo) yet, I seriously doubt this review would change your mind.

However, having played this sucker for 476 hours (at time of review), I can't think of a more polished example of a logistics/survival game. Hours fly by, you wonder why you're thirsty, and it's because you haven't taken a sip of your drink in a couple of hours. 

Each build, you learn something new, and at 470ish hours, I'm *STILL* learning.

Extremely satisfying. If I had the money, I'd pay the developers to take a crack at Dwarf Fortress. 

My only complaint is that it's almost too easy to win (it's really not, but after a few play throughs, you'll get what I mean) 

If it's not in your library, yet, I'd sincerely recommend remedying that. As far as I'm concerned, it's one of the finest games of this century in terms of polish, addictiveness and replayability. 

Love this game 10/10.

136970233.review:
not unsimilar to drugs, it looks fun but then you get really into it and by the time you're done, a couple hours have passed.
starts simple, gets complicated, you are silently made fun of for making a bad base. start over, or do some reconstructing.
there are enemies but you can turn them off. they get more powerful with more smog you create.
almost endlessly deep, with cool mechanics like trains and drones, there's a lot to do (and research) and if that's not enough for you, there's a huge modding scene with little QoL mods to entire game overhauls. game is multiplayer too and has different modes if the main game isnt your thing.

If you are looking for a game that will make you feel like a genius, a madman, or both, look no further than Factorio. Factorio is a game that will test your creativity, logic, and engineering skills as you build and maintain factories, mine resources, research technologies, automate production, and fight enemies. It is a game that will make you addicted to efficiency, optimization, and automation. It is a game that will make you forget about sleep, food, and social life.

Factorio is not just a game, it is a phenomenon. It is a game that has been created with passion, care, and attention to detail. It is a game that has been constantly updated and improved over the years, with new features, content, and optimizations. It is a game that has a vibrant and supportive community of players and modders who share their creations and feedback.

Factorio is a game that I would recommend to anyone who loves strategy, simulation, or sandbox games. It is a game that will keep you hooked for hours, days, or even weeks. It is a game that will make you think, learn, and have fun. It is a game that deserves all the praise and recognition it has received.

Factorio is a game that you should definitely play. You will not regret it. Unless you value your sanity.

Received this game from a friend and have been absolutely mind-blown how similar this functions to my current job.  I work as a software engineer and the way I approach coding is identical, in fact this entire game looks and feels like it was designed for people with a programming background. Watching Youtube videos of people setting up circuit networks is literally like the Computer Hardware course I took at university.

For me I always start small, build blueprints, copy and paste, and then create bigger and better things. Recently I put together a front-end webpage that blew a lot of my coworker's minds. It wasn't anything special.  It was just one removed from something I did the previous month, rewind three years and you find me learning how to make a very simple webpage. I feel the same way looking at some of the Factorio builds on here.

Anyways I highly recommend this game if you're a coder. And if you [i]already[/i] love this game, maybe consider going into a computer science field. At my company we cannot hire enough people. Instead of resumes I think you should be able to submit your Factorio build.

133214578.review:
From a guy that is not into base building games, and not like "top down view" games. I can already say that I pleasantly surprised.

I really hesitated to purchase this game. So I thought let's try the demo at least. What's the worst that can happen. After I finished the demo I purchased the full game. I just wanted to continue playing.

In case you think this game might not be for you, just give the demo a fair try. But make sure you have at least 2 hours to focus on the game. It's not a game where you want to be distracted from while playing.

I really enjoy playing it. It's a rather unique experience for me so far. Especially since I normally only play FPS games like HLL, Squad, CSGO etc. And I like how the game mechanics work. The top down view actually feels nice too. I also like the graphics, they are soft/pleasant. And the game runs great, had no issues so far.

I kept enemies on, but you can turn it off if you don't like it. I think it gives an extra element. You will need to protect your base. So there are more things to do/take care of. My friend doesn't like it so he turned it off. So there are options for all of that. You can make it really difficult or very easy depending on your needs. You can limit the map size or make it larger. And there are great mods (I haven't payed those but if you "finish" the game you can even continue with mods).

I soon receive a Steam Deck, and I am looking forward playing this game on it!

10/10 so far.

129745359.review:
Just this morning I tried to restore a 1970 Ford Pinto in the middle of my living room and ended up burning down my home, and turning both my wife and child into charcoal just by touching the gas tank. I was distraught because now both of the people I used to get out of social events and paying taxes were gone. I felt the weight of my event-stoked divorce and child removal pile on me like a slew of dwarfs on a grain of rice (it's a lot for them.) 

Not knowing what else to do, I booted up Factorio. My gamer gear was too epic to die in an explosion like some beta cuck, so don't ask me "Well how are you playing the game in your burnt down abode???" Immediately I felt a sense of pride and confidence as I crafted not only a mining apparatus, but a box for it to sneeze resources into. I looked to the small crater in the middle of my living room and chortled as I realized that I was a mechanical genius and my only limitation was the weight of non-virtual resources holding me back. 

I felt my fingers fly across the keys; I even saw my neighbor grow scared as I pressed W, S, A, and then D while making direct eye contact. It's been 17 years of continual play (ignore what Steam says, they're trying to hold me back). I missed the funeral, the rapture, and even the second coming of the McRib, but did I build several more boxes that make the import lot of a certain large chain grocery store, that I got banned from, look like an unzipped beanbag chair? 

You bet your sweet bippy I did.

Play the game. It really makes you escape the burden of your sins and even gives your room a nice formaldehyde-esque scent.  

I wasn't paid to write this review, but I did spend precious time I'll never get back to make sure you all know just how cash money it is.

After 400 hours I decided I am now a solid beginner, and can write a review

If you plan on having a social life, a healthy sleep schedule or deadlines, you might wanna wait until at least 2 of them are not a priority anymore. (And let's be honest, 1&2 have a great combination potential)
The drug itself plays very satisfying, watching your first base after you build about 5-10 other bases, all with a different base design, you can't help but to smile upon the cute little belt mess, that was once your proudest achievement, since it at least started a rocket. The more you play and organize your base, the more time will become an illusion, and the need for nutrition is put on second place in your brain. It's great when you want to "just hop into a round and fix one minor bottleneck" at 8 pm, and find yourself at 4 am in a biter base, armed so heavily you could use the Geneva convention as a checklist, in a spider like robot, which shoots about 10 nukes per second and walks faster then my fat uncle when my grandmother makes her famous lasagna, extinguishing approximately 500 non human lifeforms, that just wanted to live in harmony with nature, all for those 2.5m iron they're sitting on, to improve your iron gear production by 1.4% and only lasts for about 2 hours.
It's great how this game turns normal people into hyperfixiated sociopaths without any mercy, doing whatever is necessary to achieve maximum efficiency.

 I highly recommend this game to anyone.

147372136.review:
This is not a review of just the game, but a review of wube software's (not to be confused with ubisoft) market practices and development cycle as well.

Don`t be fooled by my playtime here, i have played a couple thousands of hours on the client i got at high seas and finally decided to buy it here. 

[h1]THE BIZ[/h1]

Let's start with the price tag. the game was free upon release, then it was 13 USD, then 20, now 35, and on top of that, it never goes on sale. 

Why? Surely it must be because the devs are greedy and wanna milk as much as they can from the game without having to release a new one, right?

well... no. not at all, actually. since the game was released, 'bout a decade ago, the devs have a blog in which, weekly, without missing a single week, they post about upcoming stuff for the game.  in comparison you have AAA publishers that release an unfinished game, just to abandon it during the first year of release and work on the next title, all the while charging you 100 bucks for the base game and some extra, sometimes twice the price of the base game in DLCs. 

Factorio ain't like that. You pay the price, you get the game, like it used to be. No microtransactions, no live service, no currency paid in real cash. nothing. The price you pay for the game gives you the full game, access to any and all updates to the game AND mod support, which i'll talk about in depth further below. 

[h1]THE GAME(sorry)[/h1]

Factorio isn't exactly a game for [i]everyone[/i]. It scratches a [i]very[/i] specific itch, but it does that better than any other scratcher. To one person, it could be just another boring managerial sim, while to others, it's literal crack. 

The premise is simple: you crashed on alien planet and must rebuild ship to get out of planet. Other games have similar premises, like subnautica or... well i can only remember of subnautica right now. Anyway, this recipe has been tested and tried over and over, so what's special about Factorio?

[strike]conveyor belts[/strike] simplicity.

If you have looked at screenshots or videos of the game, or even played before, "simplicity" probably isn't a word that you'd find fitting for the game, but think about how simple the game is. You only have one goal: to rebuild the rocket ship. There are no side quests, no hidden stashes marked on your minimap, nothing to distract you from your main goal. The side quests and additional content end up being the steps you have to take to rebuild the rocket. you're gonna need lots of circuit boards to build a rocket. for those you'll need plastic. do you have plastic? no you don't. you don't have oil either. you need oil to make plastic. So now your main quest, that is, build the rocket, has been superseded by your side quest: find oil. And that's how the entirety of the game goes, pulling you in the most natural way possible from one objective to the next. You can beat the game with the most Giovanni's Pasta factory you can build, or with the most optimized buses that make your factory look like a motherboard. Or something in between. It lets you do as you please and shows you in real time how effective your buildings are, and that eventually will make you wonder "Can't i make that any faster?" In a certain aspect, the game feels almost roguelike. You build your base, realize that it is now terrible and inefficient, raze it to the ground, rebuild it with new knowledge you have from the game, and eventually repeat the whole process, over and over.

One friendly reminder, though: try to get used to the keyboard shortcuts asap. it cuts down on the time you need to do things IMMENSELY. Doing everything by clicking and manually laboring will quickly make the game feel like a chore.

Oh, and i almost forgot: [b]MODS![/b]

Factorio is more akin to a sandbox engine than to an actual game. Think of it like warcraft 3 The Frozen Throne map editor, but with a few maps already done for you. You can turn factorio into a racing game. a TRAIN racing game. A zombie survival/crafting monstrosity? Very possible with mods. A tower defense game? Hell, it even comes with one standard! You like RTS and wish starcraft had more building flexibility? boy, you're not gonna believe this. You can also get more mundane stuff, like... i don't know, more powerful furnaces or whatever. With enough effort you could probably pull out a MOBA. The possibilities are nearly infinite.

[h1]THE VALUE[/h1]

So, after considering all that, is it worth it? 

I'd say try demoing the game for a few hours and see if it's your jam. Having a friend who already knows the game to explain stuff to you helps a lot. If you like the genre then it's a no brainer, get it! At the time of this review, the game has costed me about 0.3 USD/hour of entertainment, which i consider rather cheap. Considering you'll likely never play it for less than 4 hours at a time, the value gets optimal very quickly.

It should be obvious by now, judging by how many hours of playtime the average factorio player has, but the replayability is probably the best ever made. The objective is always the same, the resources are always the same, but you, the engineer, after every rebuilt factory, after every playthrough, you learn more and improve on your builds. There's always a better, or at least, different way to do what you're already doing, and you don't know how that different way will affect the outcome. So you try it.

For the quality of gameplay, fair business practices and constant updates since release, this is one of the best games on steam, which is reflected by the reviews. If you don't hate factories or crack, buy it.

141303560.review:
Factorio is an absolute gem in the world of gaming. It has captured my imagination and kept me hooked for countless hours, and I simply cannot recommend it enough!

The game revolves around the concept of automation, where you are tasked with building and managing your own industrial empire. From the moment you land on an alien planet, you'll find yourself deeply engrossed in a web of resource gathering, manufacturing, and logistics. The complexity and depth of gameplay are mind-blowing, and every decision you make feels rewarding and impactful.

The game's graphics may seem simplistic at first glance, but don't let that fool you. The attention to detail is astonishing, and the world you build becomes a vibrant, living entity. As you expand your operations, constructing intricate conveyor belt networks, setting up robotic factories, and designing efficient production lines, the satisfaction is unparalleled.

Factorio truly excels in its ability to foster creativity. The freedom to experiment and devise your own solutions to logistical challenges is incredibly empowering. Whether you prefer optimizing your supply chains, creating elaborate defense systems, or delving into complex circuit networks, the game caters to a wide range of playstyles and encourages innovative thinking.

What truly sets Factorio apart is its outstanding community and modding support. The game is filled with an incredible assortment of player-created mods that enhance and extend the game in unimaginable ways. From quality of life improvements to total conversions, the modding scene breathes new life into an already exceptional experience, ensuring that the game remains fresh and exciting for years to come.

The developers behind Factorio have crafted a masterpiece that constantly pushes the boundaries of what a game can be. Their dedication and commitment to delivering a polished and immersive experience are evident in every aspect of the game. Regular updates and the responsiveness to player feedback demonstrate their passion for their creation and the community that surrounds it.

In conclusion, Factorio is an absolute must-play for anyone who appreciates deep, challenging gameplay, limitless creativity, and a supportive and vibrant community. Brace yourself for a thrilling journey of automation and discovery. Get ready to lose yourself in a world of gears, belts, and science. Factorio is a true testament to the wonders that gaming can offer.

Disclaimer: The reviewer has spent an embarrassingly large number of hours playing Factorio and has no regrets whatsoever.

140943552.review:
Factorio is a game that transcends traditional gaming experiences, offering an unparalleled level of depth and satisfaction for those who appreciate the art of automation and strategic planning. Developed by Wube Software, Factorio has established itself as a true gem in the gaming world, capturing the hearts and minds of players around the globe.

From the moment you step foot into the vast and intricate world of Factorio, you are thrust into a beautifully crafted sandbox of industry and innovation. The game challenges you to build and optimize sprawling factories, mining resources, researching technologies, and designing intricate production lines. As you progress, the complexity and scale of your operations expand, providing an addictive gameplay loop that keeps you engrossed for hours on end.

One of the defining features of Factorio is its incredible attention to detail. The developers have meticulously crafted a game world where every cog and gear has a purpose, making each decision you make crucial to the overall success of your factory. The sense of accomplishment that comes from optimizing your production chain, reducing bottlenecks, and seeing your factory operate like a well-oiled machine is unparalleled.

Factorio's gameplay mechanics are a work of art. The game strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and complexity, allowing players of all skill levels to enjoy its addictive gameplay. Whether you're a seasoned strategist or new to the world of resource management games, Factorio offers a gentle learning curve that gradually introduces new concepts and mechanics, ensuring you're always engaged and challenged.

The level of freedom and creativity in Factorio is truly remarkable. The game grants you the ability to design and customize your factory in any way you see fit. The vast array of automation tools and building options gives you the power to experiment and devise ingenious solutions to problems. The satisfaction of optimizing your factory layout, implementing efficient transportation systems, and watching your creations come to life is deeply rewarding.

In addition to its captivating single-player campaign, Factorio boasts a robust multiplayer mode that allows you to collaborate or compete with friends and players from around the world. The multiplayer experience adds a whole new layer of excitement, enabling you to tackle challenges and build grand factories together, further enhancing the game's longevity.

Factorio is more than just a game; it's an addictive journey that challenges your problem-solving skills, creativity, and ability to think on your feet. It is a testament to the passion and dedication of the developers, who have created a masterpiece that continues to evolve and captivate players even after countless hours of gameplay.

If you're a fan of strategy, automation, and the satisfaction of building something truly remarkable, then Factorio is an absolute must-play. Prepare to lose yourself in a world of industrial wonders, where your ingenuity and determination shape the course of progress. Factorio is a shining example of what gaming can achieve when craftsmanship and innovation converge, and it deserves its place among the greatest games of all time

140568919.review:
So I have 5K hours. Yea that happend. I was just enjoying the game. And when I got bored installed mods and played those. Then got bored of those and started another modpack. Then came back to the base game. Then to that first modpack. Then someone made a new overhaul mod. And at somepoint I had a list of multiple modpacks I still wanted to play.

I easily log 60+ hours weeks when I enjoy a run of this game. Time just slips by without notice and then you suddenly log 4940 hours. But you have yet to get all the achievements. So a few more vanilla runs and then boom you are at 5K.

But lets take the time to not talk about the time I enjoyed on this game. The game is really optimised. The only true issues I have had with crashes was playing modpacks with 30+ mods that created really weird edge cases for the game. In vanilla I have yet to crash a game or desync a multiplayer game. The game has 'experiemental' versions that are more stable then some other games at their most stable. The amount of love this game gets from its developers is insane.

140237391.review:
it's Factorio, the factory game so iconic that you can find companion apps on google play. what can i say?
the base game itself is great, being simple once you get the hang of it, un-optimized gameplay works, however as in many games the fun comes in finding just how well you can do it, and how well the game is optimized leaves plenty of room for that. however, the extensive modding support (built straight into the main menu) and community allow changes to the game, ranging from quality of life improvements, to complete overhauls of gameplay, to renai transportation. 

The sound design complements the visuals and overall aesthetic very well, That of a lonely grungy world being terraformed into your personal shrine to industy. you will often find yourself thinking you heard an inserter whirring, or seeing belts in empty space.

Wube software, the developers for this title, are one of the devs i hold in higher respects, they embrace the community, as is rare in larger studios. they gifted us with native linux support, for the 3 other people using linux, and you can download the game DRM free off their website

All in all, if this game looks at all appealing to you, i would recommend first reading a better review, and second, try the game out, if you don't like it, steam will refund it as long as you play for less than 2 hours, alternatively there is a demo available

i rate it five air conditioners out of seven pineapples.

140184687.review:
I hesitantly recommend this to anyone that likes management games in general. Prior experience in factory games specifically is absolutely not required, although this game might sour you on other factory games in the future.

My hesitation is not because the game is bad. For the most part, it is because the game is [i]good beyond reason[/i]. This is the kind of game that is entrancing, where you can sit down to play at 6 PM, look at the clock what you think is 2 hours later, and find it's 2 AM. And at times it feels like it is forcing that playstyle on you, because of just how hard it can be to figure out what you were doing when you come back for another session after a break of any significant length.

All in all, my suggestion is to play vanilla for something like 100 hours and then [i]never install an overhaul mod[/i]. Those things can and will unironically derail your real life with how engaging and time-consuming they are. The vast majority of my logged hours are on overhaul mods (although a large chunk are actually AFK).

139464316.review:
The single greatest game you and i will ever play in our whole life to the point where the cons are that its too good (way too addicting), but honestly, that regional price raise was way too much, this is quite literally just hissing away new players to their crack sources (i almost stayed but the community was too good i had to get the game)
as for the USD currency, the game just sat right with everyone on 30.00 hell it even looked cool and fit the game but thats irrelevant, isnt it? in my opinion its a must try, not a must buy
putting that aside (which is kind of difficult tbh, no one likes unneeded greed), the developers are very dedicated to making this game flawless, you can even degrade to any update directly from the steam betas which is awesome to fully utilize the seamless multiplayer.

as for the game itself:
for some the game forces them to think, for some the game will only be a lengthy procedure and either way the game is fun for both the mature and teen-age audience, you can make a cool factory that looks good with sorting and them fancy materials to build the a nice and cozy factory OR you can make an unpleasant yet efficient factory (pro tip try to sort your stuff in the beginning, you dont want your conveyors to be italian food unless its your favorite type of pasta, i wont judge), on the other side of the game you need to protect your base from aliens by automating ammo refill for turrets, laser turrets which consume electricity but are weak later in the game so you need a lot of them and lot of electricity, flame throwers which consume different types of oil each giving them different stats, basically a more complicated and lengthy tower defense (set-up your defense well, no one likes getting their factory eaten by biters :/ )

there's awesome robots like the logistic robots which by its name you should know that its autonomous (it can transfer items :D)  you can use it instead of conveyor belts for some messy setups to make them a little bit better, theres also a blueprint system where you can save your nice outpost architecture for later use, solar panels build, steam engines and boilers, and with that copy+paste system comes the holy building robots, these bad boys do the building when you paste a build (if you there's some where you are at atleast) the logistic robots tells the building robots where they can find the items needed (you should have them automated with everything else including miners, turrets, furnaces) and they build, and if you have them everywhere you can even build right from the map, no 300km walking session :)


theres also very well made trains that make everything so much more fun, a common example of what you do in factorio is making a mining outpost away from your base on a good ore vein and using a locomotive you automatically refill your turrets by using inserters to grab the ammo that you should have already automated to be put in the first cargo wagon before the train proceeds to the mining destination,and you use the locomotive to transfer the ores from that mining outpost to the furnaces (by inserting the ores to the second cargo wagon) which you use inserters to output the ores from the cargo to a chest for each inserter and use another inserters to extract from the chest to the conveyor belt which moves them to the furnaces and then you cook them iron plates! (iron deficiency)

theres 3 types of generating power: solar panels and accumulators, steam engines and boilers, nuclear power and steam turbines later in the game, although i wish nuclear reactors were complicated and not just make 4 and place them, get the uranium ore in the centrifuge and connect the output with conveyors close to the reactors, put some inserters to grab the uranium fuel cells and insert it in the reactors and put turbines here and there and kaboom  [strike]explosion[/strike] its now working yay :D

theres so much in the game that im too lazy to mention, try the demo its great, its the first bit of the game (which lasts like 6-10 hours i think), but keep in mind the game just has so much content for a demo to give an accurate idea of.
but anyways

The Factory Must Grow.

139177996.review:
A game like Factorio will send you on an emotional rollercoaster with heartwarming happiness and severe anguish. The sensation of achievement is unfathomable, from the thrilling beginning of a crash landing on a foreign planet to creating a vast manufacturing empire. The thrill of streamlining processes and automating whatever you can is comparable to enjoying a properly cooked steak while listening to your favourite music.

But don't be fooled by the seeming simplicity; Factorio's challenge is just as genuine as walking barefoot on a LEGO block. When you believe you have everything under control, the game throws a wrench (or a dozen) into your well-functioning system. Your factory is invaded by alien biters, which causes a panic similar to a cat chasing a laser pointer. The balancing of the electrical grid turns into a unicycle juggling show with flaming chainsaws.

The dark comedy of Factorio will have you second-guessing your decisions and considering a simpler life as a hermit in the woods. But in the middle of frustration, innovations occur, and your factory once again hums with productivity. The delicious win justifies the nerve-wracking times.

This game takes pleasure in both your triumph and your misery. It will simultaneously make you feel smart and stupid. But despite everything, you'll be enthralled by the game's compelling gameplay and the prospect of building the ideal mechanized paradise. You'll laugh, weep, and undoubtedly curse like a drunken pirate on Factorio's gloriously chaotic trip.

I sincerely urge any daring factory builders to check out Factorio. Accept the happiness and the sorrow, and remember that they are all a part of the experience. Happy engineering, and long live the spaghetti-free factory!

138175958.review:
I started out playing Satisfactory and Dyson Sphere Program before ever playing Factorio. I added this game to my lineup to play and have been hooked ever since. For some reason, I love city-building and logistics games. They appeal to my sense of order and organization. It has a little bit of a learning curve. Once you get the game mechanics down, your play starts to speed up. As for me, I stream my games and tend to slow my movements down so they are fluid on the stream. Just be forewarned... You will get hooked on this game if you enjoy games like this.

Edit 1: This game has really taken a lot of my time. It is such a well-designed game. I started this game over at least a dozen times trying to improve the new game with what I have learned as I progressed. I finally realized I should not have done this and concentrated on progressing the game. I did a lot of deconstruction to improve on what I learned.

Edit 2: With the recent FFFs and knowing what is coming, I am really looking forward to the new content, especially trains. It is amazing how your mind constantly thinks about this game and the improvements you can make. No two games are the same.

136854658.review:
Factorio has the same property as Minecraft in that it captivates you completely for short but intense bursts, sometimes if you are thoroughly unlucky, you may find yourself enthralled by it for up to a month. Eventually though, you end up moving on, to come back to it once again months later. Factorio is, aside from the enemies of course, one of the most bug-free games available, which is a considerable achievement considering how intricate the game can be. It is also incredibly intuitive in its controls. 

The only thing I would criticise Factorio for is that the ghost system could be better. For example, you have to enable the option to place ghosts if the thing you wish to place is unavailable, which I think should be a default. Also, you can't place ghosts of items you haven't unlocked via research. Finally, you can't just use ghosts to plan. They are combined into the same system that construction robots use to build, so if you want to plan something out first without it being built or things in the way removed, you have to either shut down the bots or build out of their range deliberately.
