136611372.review:
What can I say, I already have 4000hs in this game, and I bought it Feb 2021... that's more than two years of constant enjoyment I got from it.

If you let it, this game can become your second life and steal everything from you, so just be careful... treat it with care!

I like to review games when I complete them (i.e. 100% achievements) and I just got the last two achievements for this one: took two weeks of practicing attempts and designing a base that could be (partially) quickly built by hand initially, and made in such a way that you can rush robots as soon as possible.  Have to say that half the fun was designing such a base and half was actually building it! 

What can I say about the game? Hmm... here are probably plenty of other reviews already for this game praising it and making memes ofc. that I won't have anything innovative or insightful to say at all.

The thing that absorbs me into this game, is the almost infinite ways in you can play it, all the variations in the way you can build things, all the mods and the fact that it scratches a specific creative itch that no other game seem to be able to scratch.

From the speedrun achievements I just did to the megabases from back a few months, from the complicated mod packs I tried to the heavy combat based overhauls. I've been doing a bit of everything and got my fair share of enjoyment from all of that.

As an electronics based engineer I used to route PCBs back in the day, and this game is very reminiscent of that: electronics circuits laid out in a PCB board... but you also have to design what's inside the ICs.  There's something magical about deciding how to partition complex processes, how to connect them, then routing those connections and seeing them work.

The best bases I saw over my time playing this game work like a clockwork mechanism and it's often beautiful to watch them go, but even if you've got a base that is not perfect, it's also immensely rewarding to analyse it and try to understand why it isn't working well, and see how doing small tweaks and fixes here and there, produces changes down the line. 

The game is very simulation based, i.e. it's more like a precise simulation than a game: how it all works, and makes sense and has a reason behind it. The way you can form complex parts from simpler ones, and the different forms you can combine them, is what gives this game it's amazing qualities.

I do think that this is one of those games that everyone should try, at least once. It helps in developing your organizational and planning skills, and also applying math, logic, programming and the general creativity needed to design stuff.

Not to forget, that, in case it's not enough, you can make logical circuits inside this game that can compute things and run logic... you can make crazy control logic that can automate things to a level that's almost comparable to a commercial PLC (though the "language" used is kinda annoying to work with...) and people has made at least 8 bits CPUs running inside Factorio.

There's also the combat aspect and the enemies, which... I don't have much to say, I don't like that aspect enough to want to engage too much with it, but luckily the game lets you customize everything and make enemies as relevant (or irrelevant) as you want, even removing them altogether, if you like a pest-free playground :P

136138814.review:
Factorio is a simulation game where you try to reenact as many scenes from Star-Ship troopers as you possibly can (jk)

Factorio is the ultimate factory building and management simulation puzzle game where one of the biggest challenges is figuring out the best ways to move ore to and from your furnaces and then figure out how to move those items to other places. It's a deceptively simple gameplay loop of 
1. move items
2. make items
3. move items again
Its a loop that quickly spirals out of control until you're left with a gigantic mass of machines all creating and moving items around and by the end of it you have no idea how any of it is working but you're glad it is because if it wasn't working the bugs would tear through the walls and eat your glorious green chip factories causing a 1% decrease in chip production which doesn't sound like allot but after a while it starts to drive you insane because you haven't left the house in a month and people keep texting and asking if you're okay but you're okay and just playing Factorio because if you're not playing Factorio then how are you going to play Factorio? 
The reason I call Factorio a puzzle game is because the more you add on to your factory the more challenging it becomes to add more as your crafted items increase in both complexity and scarcity all while tidal wave after tidal wave of monstrous insects try to eat their way through your defenses, this is Factorios most fun quality the more stuff you make the more stuff you need to make in order to keep the ball rolling creating a gameplay loop that can go on as long as you want it to as you increase your items per hour from 10k to 20k all the way up to 100M if you really wanted to. 

The Factory must grow but how much that is and how complex is completely up to you as the player! Don't be discouraged by people who can build the gigantic million trillion item per second factories cause that can be you one day! Also don't be afraid to look up tutorials if you get stuck or need help this game has one of the most helpful and friendly communities out there full of people ready to tell you all about their new build that gave them a 0.5% increase in production.

There is allot of fun and replayability crammed into this deceivingly simple game and I would recommend it to anyone who likes a brain teaser or management simulations.

Factorio is for you if you like the resource management of Warcraft and the tech trees of Civilization. You are a lone engineer, crash landed on a hostile planet with easy-to-mine resources and the ability to research new tech and automation. 135093203.review:
This game is a flawless combination of a puzzler and a management game with a fair survival mode thrown in. There is a vibrant modding community on top of this. I do not normally find myself missing a more 3d world like is in satisfactory. Both are good games. Mods are pretty optional. Maps are randomly generated.

The puzzle side of the game is in finding layouts that work well. Each tile can only have one thing on it, so if you have a 6 lane highway of goods, you can't just shrink it to one lane without penalties to how well things work.

Don't buy this type of game if: You hate math or puzzles and are impatient to see cool things. It is playable in 20 minute to one hour sessions with small goals. But there is not a ton of story and some of the milestones will take 2 hours to achieve after the prior one.

Buy this if: you find the idea cool, can tolerate 8-9th grade algebra (even if you don't use it) and like a genuine feeling of achievement for meeting targets. Most players eventually turn the survival aspects off. It adds to the challenge but not the replay value. My Pro-tip would be to turn base expansion off the first time you play.

Buy Mindustry if you want survival mode to be central to the game.

Buy satisfactory if you want the additional fun of a platformer and exploration game on a predesigned map. It also has the best semi-creative building system of any game I have played. However, it has no real survival beyond learning how to handle aliens while exploring; and I find the management of resources far more nuisancesome than in Factorio.

134577006.review:
Factorio is a unique and engaging game that combines resource management, strategy, and survival elements in a way that is both challenging and satisfying. With a vast and diverse world that includes everything from dangerous crustaceans and pesky fungi to towering stumps and vicious toothy beasts, the game keeps players on their toes at all times.

One of the standout features of Factorio is its emphasis on creating efficient production lines, using everything from paper and pulp to meat and soy. It's a game that rewards careful planning and execution, while also providing plenty of opportunities for experimentation and creativity.

In addition to its addictive gameplay, Factorio also boasts an incredible soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's industrial aesthetic. And with a lively and passionate community of players, there's never a shortage of people to play and trade tips with.

Of course, no review of Factorio would be complete without mentioning the game's incredible graphics and attention to detail. From the soaring planes that dot the sky to the curmudgeonly old grandmas that occasionally pop up to offer advice, every aspect of the game is meticulously crafted and rendered.

All in all, Factorio is a must-play game for anyone who loves strategy, survival, and resource management games. So grab a bag of soy chips, fire up the game, and get ready to embark on the adventure of a lifetime!

134469851.review:
In short: 10/10, Super Addictive Gameplay − The Factorio Must Grow.
∙ The mechanics are well thought out and allow for many creative solutions for even the most basic tasks. The finiteness of the resources forces you to plan ahead and always be on your toes. Because of this, there is always something to do, and always room to improve your previous creations. (These are not things I can say about some other games of this genre...)
∙ High replayability thanks to the procedurally generated terrain and the many settings you can change on map-creation. This includes the difficulty of the enemies, which is configurable from non-existant, over passive, all the way to brutal. Great for new-commers and veterans alike.
∙ Extremely moddable: Anything is possible! Go to space! Get stuck on an island! Nuke the planet! Get eaten by aliens 100 times your size!
∙ Very good performance. The programmers clearly know what they are doing, and they have even described some of their optimizations in a blog.

134326590.review:
If you're into simulation or management games, Factorio is a must-play! This game has captured the hearts and minds of players all over the world, and it's not hard to see why. Developed by Wube Software since 2012, Factorio is one of the most polished and refined games available on Steam today.

Factorio is a game that offers a lot of quality, despite being much cheaper than other AAA games. You get addictive gameplay, impressive level of detail, and a modding community that is just thriving. Seriously, there are countless mods that add new features, expand the game world, and enhance the gameplay experience in a variety of ways. It's pretty cool to see how creative and dedicated the modding community is.

The game revolves around building and managing a complex industrial system, with the goal of automating as much of the process as possible. It starts with basic resources, but as you progress through the game, the challenges become increasingly difficult. But trust me, the satisfaction of building a well-oiled machine is truly addictive.

Overall, Factorio is an incredible game that offers a truly unique and engaging gameplay experience. The developers and modding community have put so much effort into it, making it one of the best games on Steam. If you're looking for a game that you can pour hundreds or thousands of hours into, Factorio is definitely worth checking out. You'll love the addictive gameplay, impressive attention to detail, and the thriving modding community that always keeps the game fresh and exciting.

134151554.review:
For anyone with an engineering type brain, this game is like some form of "super crack". My day job is as a software engineer and this game scratches all the same itches that led me into said career. I've picked this game up to play a few minutes and then seemingly fallen into a gravity well. What feels like 5 minutes can turn into hours of building, re-building, and debugging my factories.

the "vanilla" game is definitely fun and an excellent value for ~100+ hours at whatever they're currently charging. But this game really shines when it comes to the sometimes complete game overhauls that are possible with the in-game mod system. Space Exploration + Krastorio 2 is a personal favorite. I'm on my second playthrough attempt (~26 hrs or so) after getting ~160 hrs or so into my first playthrough. I started a new one because after a couple hundred hours of experience I found some better QOL mods to play with and I had a better idea of how the game settings I wanted to play with. "Vanilla" is great to play with biters in the default settings (maybe a slightly larger starting area), but SE + K2 is a bear if you have to deal with pollution and biter expansion. Pyanodons or Nullius mod-packs will likely be my next playthrough after finishing SE + K2 (still hundreds of hours away). The value of this game with the overhaul mods is absolutely insane!

I also look forward to what the devs have in store for the game expansion. Hopefully it keeps to the same quality and adds even more value to this amazing game.

I can honestly say that this is one of my all-time favorite games. The only game I have more time in is Apex on console, but that is only because of weekly games with friends (plus I've been playing that since launch in 2019). I have nearly 500 hours across Nintendo Switch and Steam (mainly on the Deck) since only November of last year.

Highly recommend for those that like challenge and production-line design.

133234907.review:
I had Factorio on my wishlist for a few years. I bought it on January 21, when I heard about the upcoming price increase.  I first played it on February 4. Today is February 20, it took  me 18 hours of tutorials and 60 hours of actual playing to finish the game. That makes it almost 5 hours per day for more than two weeks. The game is so great and so addictive!

With a first game I barely scratched its surface, I feel I can spend hundreds of hours of quality time tinkering with my base, expanding, building infrastructure, occasionally going in expeditions to pacify the planet.

The game is scaling up in a very controllable and beginner friendly way, I was first afraid that while I thought about how to build the base, the natives will kill me, or they would get stronger before I could prepare proper defenses. But actually threat of natives is scaling up mostly with base development, not with time, so one has the luxury to think how to develop the base. 

I died three times and reloaded autosave, this  is something I normally do not do, I play ironman with no reloads on strategy games, but those deaths were linked with learning the game: the trains ran me over twice and I built a railway crossing with traffic lights (railway signals); I died once in the alien toxic spit, I was not aware I had to move away from it.

I liked the best that you can spend a lot of time designing the base, but when invariably, the design needs to change, you do not lose the buildings and belts, you just un-deploy them. This makes it so much easier and fun to re-design. The only think lost are the liquids in the pipes.

I need to take a break from playing now, it risks affecting my normal life.

133067187.review:
I'm certain this has already been said, but the amount of grief I've seen this game get lately due to the price change is absolutely unwarranted.

The current gaming industry is overflowing with toxic and anti-consumer practices that make me sick. There are more studios than ever before with access to better technology than has ever been available, yet pre-orders, micro-transactions, cosmetics, and subscriptions plague games that are over-marketed, lack content, release while unfinished, and remain unsupported. These are the "greedy practices" that have ruined a depressing amount of potentially timeless experiences.

I have yet to see any of this nonsense from Factorio or Wube Software. The game continues to be updated by the developer. Wube strongly supports and incorporates a modding community that has drastically increased the value of the base game over time. In this case, never putting your game on sale is overwhelmingly pro-consumer. Fallout 76 went on sale a month after release, which just meant that everyone that had already bought it had over-paid for that game. Anyone who bought 76 overpaid for the game. The value of the game is protected when it never goes on sale because when you buy it, that's it. No subscriptions, and no grief over not waiting one more week for it to drop 50%. 

Then the price is increased by $5. They say because of inflation; I don't know about that, but really who cares? Are you forced to pay another $5 if you already owned it? For anyone who has been enjoying this game any time between 2016 when it came out in early access and January 2023, it's irrelevant. You already own that value. It is absolutely mind-boggling that people are upset over this. If you cared about the game enough to be upset about a price hike, you would have already owned it. We should be celebrating a developer who has continued to refine a game to the point where it warrants a price increase, not saying bullshit like "don't reward bad practice". This is the opposite of bad practice.

Rant complete. And since this is a review, yes, the game was well worth the $30 I paid for it in 2018. It would be worth $35 if I were buying it today. Wube will continue to have my support as long as they continue to treat consumers and their community with respect as they have so far.

132033134.review:
I'll be ignoring the games pricing policy in this review. Also ignore my bad wording, it's 1am and the factory is calling me.

Factorio is a simple game: mine ore, process it, use it to research better machines and repeat until you launch your first rocket all while protecting you from those pesky biters. The true beauty lies in your factories ability to scale to unbelievable levels, just look up some mega factories to be amazed, but don't be intimidated. You too can build these enormous factories, the best strategy to build these after launching a rocket is to give yourself goals like researching all sciences, launching a rocket every x minutes, getting all achievements,  … If you are stuck at some point you can always rely on the amazing userbase who will gladly help you. Another tip I’ll give you is to not immediately look up blueprints when you can’t think of a solution to produce something, try creating your own designs and see where you can improve them. 

If your starting to get bored of the base game you’ll be impressed by the incredible amount of mods, many of these are basically new games (space exploration, seablock, …) and offer new playstyles. Other mods add QOL features (even distribution is the best) or just some new machines or weapons to exterminate some biters. 

The best thing about Factorio is that you can play it with friends, the game even offers some scenarios where you compete against them to see who builds the best factory.

A downside of the game is that the graphics aren’t as fancy as some other factory building games out there. 

I can’t really think of many more things to say, so if you want Factorio be sure to try the demo first and may your factory grow!

131325829.review:
Factorio is a fairly good game with a focus on base building and automation, where you start with basically nothing and try to work your way up to basically dominating an entire planet with factories producing pretty much anything you could possibly need. There is a high degree of focus on organizational throughput and efficient output, which may sound uninteresting at first glance, but I highly recommend trying out this or a game like this to at least get the experience first before casting judgement. I say this as someone who was once skeptical about the entertainment value of creating digital assembly lines, but it turns out that this is a very satisfying gameplay loop. You decide on an item to produce at a certain amount that you want over a set amount of time, then make a system to deliver that item at a specific rate so that you can use them to unlock or in the process of producing new and better items. While that may sound dry (and while it is a very calculation-heavy experience) it doesn't feel dissimilar to heavy grinding in an RPG where you grind in an area to unlock a good skill, that you can then use to grind in a better area for a better skill later. The visuals and plenty of design choices also have a certain charm to them worth noting. Visually, it reminds me of a classic RTS I might have played some as a small child, and the limitations created by being both a top-down 2D game as well as how plenty of the items used in automation work, it makes for even more interesting gameplay due to potentially complicating the organizational process.

That doesn't mean the game is flawless however. Some of those charming item complications can still be frustrating to deal with. In addition, despite much of the game benefiting from well-calculated production lines, the information presented in-game feels almost useless to the player unless they do even more calculation to come up with the information on production themselves. Or resort to using a third party to do the calculation for you. For instance, if you look at an assembler (mark 1) that's been placed, it's production time listed is 0.5. Not 0.5 a second, just 0.5. This meaning that it is equal to half the player's speed of crafting, which is about 3 and a half seconds if I remember. These bits of extra effort to figure out how much over what period of time, can really add up and makes the experience much less enjoyable for me. Not everyone will agree on that front, but with a game focused on efficiency as much as this one is, I find the unnecessary complication of lacking item information to be unfortunate. It doesn't ruin the game completely for me, but it surprisingly goes a long way in making me prefer other games of this style more than this one. If that doesn't bother you at all, you'll probably love this game and I hope you enjoy losing a few hundred hours of life in trying to make your world have the best factory efficiency possible to build cool stuff like robots.

128832649.review:
I've been playing Factorio for a while now, and I have to say, it's one of the most addicting games I've ever played. Whether I'm playing solo or with friends, I always find myself coming back for more.

One of the things that makes Factorio so great is the multiplayer aspect. Playing with friends adds a feeling of camaraderie and really brings something special to the game. Working together to build and manage our factory is a hugely satisfying experience, and it's a lot of fun to strategize and coordinate our efforts.

The concept of synergy is also a key factor in the game's appeal. Each person has their own role to play in the factory, and working together effectively is crucial to success. This requires communication, teamwork, and coordination, which makes for a highly engaging and satisfying experience.

But perhaps the most enjoyable aspect of "Factorio" is the goal of killing the alien protesters. These creatures are constantly attacking the factory and must be eliminated in order to protect it. This is a fun and satisfying aspect of the game, as it allows players to feel like they are really making a difference and defending their territory.

The concept of throughput is also a big part of what makes "Factorio" so addicting. This refers to the efficiency with which resources are used and items are produced, and it's something that players are constantly striving to improve. Whether it's optimizing production lines or finding new ways to gather resources, there is always room for improvement, which keeps players coming back for more.

Overall, "Factorio" is a really great game, especially with multiplayer. The sense of camaraderie and teamwork, combined with the satisfaction of expanding and improving the factory, make for a truly addicting experience. The concepts of synergy and throughput add a layer of depth and strategy to the game, and the goal of killing the alien protesters is a fun and rewarding aspect. If you haven't tried "Factorio" yet, I highly recommend it.

128714608.review:
I sat on Factorio for a loooong time. 
I enjoy city/factory building games like Satisfactory, City Skylines, etc. but factorio looks old and messy from the screenshots- I couldn't comprehend the hostile attack mechanic being anything but annoying. So I didn't bother with it for a while. 
When I finally bit the bullet I got totally sucked in. 

The good: 
- That hostile enemy mechanic? Yeah it's fantastic. The biters serve as the pressure to progress as they evolve over time, if you can't keep up you will be overrun. You cannot simply expand your factory without some consideration to the location of biter bases and the effect this may have on your base. A great way to keep the pacing of the game up. 

- Mechanics are complex enough to be interesting, but simple enough to not be frustrating. 

- There's a lot of in-depth tutorials and playable scenarios built into the game to help you learn. I personally skipped all of these, got stuck, and went back... they're pretty helpful. 

The bad:

- Despite how much is explained to you, there is still a pretty steep learning curve. While this may be a good thing for some people, I personally found it a little frustrating that so much of my early play time was essentially wasted because I did not know some relatively basic things. (I may also just be stupid).

Alright so after spending 75 ish hours on this game I'd say it's pretty great. I tried multiple times in the past to play this game but never really got further than green science, or oil. Then I would take a break and restart months later. Sometimes I'd turn the bitters on and sometimes off. But recently I decided to sit down and try to "tackle" factorio. 
My latest attempt at playing this gaming was one were I put the settings for the "rail world", where it makes resources far more abundant, but also further away, encouraging trains. And I really liked the trains. I also turned the bitters off, cause I can handle them, they just became too much a distraction from building the main base. Anyways, after 28 hours I beat factorio on these settings. Just sending the rocket into space. My factory wasn't the cleanest, and I felt like I was constantly fixing bottlenecks or logistic problems all the way till the end. Where my base was just limping trying to build the rocket.
But still after all of that I had a great time. I don't know if I will return to this game, probably will, but it was a fun time. Though do be careful it is pretty addicting. I started seeing belts and filters when I closed my eyes after playing this game for a few hours, lol.
I also now get why people find this one so great and what other games with automation have been inspired by from this game. I know this isn't the game that started the automation genre, but I do feel like I can feel the DNA of this game in other games as well.

139345348.review:
One of the GOATs. Many simple mechanics, for you to apply in complex ways. It's sort of like a puzzle game, but each individual puzzle is very simple. The challenge is that there are a lot of those small ones and they have to be pieced together with greater and greater intricacy. When you learn of a new way to solve an older problem, you might just gleefully destroy everything you've built to rebuild it better.

This game doesn't play tricks to keep you engaged. There's no grind for permanent character upgrades, RNG bs, fetch quests, pay to win, "seasons", or whatever. It's simply one of the most engaging, cerebral experiences in gaming.

The modding community is amazing and the depth of available overhaul mods is unreal. You could easily spend a thousand hours playing variants of the base game without getting bored. Then you can get one of half a dozen major overhaul mods that each add a huge amount of their own new, unique mechanics. I just started one that adds about 400hrs, and there are larger/longer ones than that.

138162799.review:
This game is the benchmark for factory building games, no other game can really compete.

Its balanced, Polished, well thought-out, Simple, yet complex and you can scale up forever(if you like) with automation.
it can be played at a very basic level or at a very high level.

Other games have tried to imitate factorio using some extra gimmick(in 3D, in space, tower defence etc) almost all of them (while enjoyable) fall short of factorio's scale, scope, features, slickness etc.

Factorio also has great mod support with some incredible DLC quality mods, 
"space exploration" is amazing, building spaceships and orbital platforms.
"Bobs mods" adds fun new things to make the game more complex.
"Seablock" caters to pure building players.
the list goes on.

I can't really say enough good things about factorio, for me its the game that defines the genre.

I guess my only complaint would be that it's probably less accessible for people new to this type of game.  the huge size is probably frightening and complex to call of duty players.   The steam statistics shows most people never manage to complete the game.  I suppose the downside is, factorio can be played for a long time!

I would probably suggest mindustry for people looking for a simpler game that can run 15min missions on a tablet.   
Factorio "can" be completed in under an 2 hours, but...  your going to be playing for at least a week.

142176461.review:
This game starts innocently enough, but before you know it, you're knee-deep in an industrial rabbit hole, frantically crafting conveyor belts and assembling machines like a mad scientist on steroids.

I thought I had my life together until I played Factorio. Now, I spend more time optimizing my virtual factory than I do sleeping. My friends ask me if I'm okay, but they just don't understand the joy of automating everything! I have belts carrying iron, coal, and my sanity. If only I could automate my real-life chores as effectively...

Warning: Factorio will mess with your perception of time. You'll think you've played for an hour, but in reality, it's been a week, and your boss is about to file a missing person report. I recommend installing an alarm clock that slaps you awake every few hours, just so you remember to eat, sleep, and maybe even breathe.

The graphics might not be jaw-dropping, but they're like the dorky high school crush you secretly adored. The real beauty lies in the intricate gameplay and the satisfaction of seeing your automated empire thrive. Who needs AAA explosions when you have the symphony of humming machines?

In conclusion, Factorio is the ultimate addiction for aspiring engineers, chaos enthusiasts, and those who think Tetris is child's play. It'll test your patience, creativity, and most importantly, your ability to function in the real world. Factorio, thank you for making me the CEO of my own imaginary factory and the laughingstock of my family and friends. I wholeheartedly recommend it... unless you value your social life, in which case, run for your life!

140123191.review:
Oh, boy, buckle up for the rollercoaster of a review I'm about to unleash on the unassuming world of Factorio! Prepare your taste buds for a zesty explosion of nonsensical delight!

Factorio, oh Factorio, you cheeky little factory-building masterpiece! This game is like a spicy salsa of mechanical mayhem. From the moment you fire up the game, you're thrust into a hypnotic trance, conducting an orchestra of industrial madness.

Picture this: a bevy of metallic ants crawling across your screen, spewing out contraptions that defy the laws of physics. It's like a surreal ballet of gears and gizmos, each pirouette more absurd than the last. You'll find yourself entranced, questioning your sanity as you embark on this chaotic journey.

The graphics, oh, the graphics! They're like a piñata of psychedelic wonder, bursting with colors that tickle your retinas. It's as if the developers summoned a troupe of caffeinated monkeys armed with paintbrushes to craft a hallucinatory dreamscape. Prepare to have your eyeballs melted and reassembled into a kaleidoscope of neon delight!

The gameplay is a fiesta of confusion and logic-defying puzzles. You'll spend hours wrangling belts, assembling contraptions, and battling hordes of alien creatures with nothing but your trusty wrench. It's like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube while riding a unicycle on a tightrope across a volcano. Utterly bonkers, I tell you!

Factorio's soundtrack is the sonic equivalent of a fiesta in your ears. It's a wild fusion of techno beats, mariachi melodies, and the occasional squealing of robotic parrots. Each track is designed to make your hips sway and your heart race, even if you're just sitting on your sofa, munching on a bag of nachos.

And let's not forget the multiplayer experience! Picture this: a raucous soirée of gamers, shouting orders, frantically tinkering with contraptions, and occasionally bursting into spontaneous dance-offs. It's like a virtual mosh pit of engineering enthusiasts, all vying for the coveted title of "Supreme Factory Overlord."

In conclusion, Factorio is a zesty, mind-bending extravaganza that defies all rational thought. It's a game that challenges your senses, tickles your imagination, and makes you question the very fabric of reality. So, grab your sombrero, unleash your inner mad scientist, and dive headfirst into this spicy vortex of mechanical insanity!

126839780.review: Factorio is a game about automation. Literally everything can be automated and should be. There are so many different ways to enjoy the fruits to your labour it feels almost surreal. Factorio is unique in it's birds eye view of a pixelated world about automation and it's really fun to play ! There are so many different ways you can automate stuff, initially you need to manual everything but eventually things will be automated. However, automation comes with a drawback! Things will get more and more complicated so you can't just blindly charge into the automation industry without a plan. There are loads of different items and each are unique while the goal is to build a spaceship to fly to space, there is really no 'true' ending and you can keep flying spaceships without anything holding you back. Overall, Factorio is a really good game and It's automation core gameplay really knows no bounds. A seal of recommendation  from me and a 9.6/10.

128896151.review:
LOVE this game.

as you can see by my hours, at the time of writing this, i have 4670 hours in this game. Yes, you read that right, four thousand hours. I CANNOT get enough of this game. The level of problem solving is JUST right, and also depends on how much thought you put into optimizing things and streamlining them.

I am only recently (as in the last 1000 hours), learning just how important the blueprint system is. It's basically the new game+ feature, but....more advanced. You can take your blueprints into ANY map, and as long as the recipes are the same, you will have a design that you can refine more and more. So save those old maps (if you dare), and come back later when you have better designs!

I OFTEN start new games just because i refined my designs, and don't want to fix the old structures. I have one map that i have about 2500 hours in. I keep coming back to that one after finding new designs and trying them out in that old map to see how effective it is in a MUCH bigger base.

Also, i haven't even touched mods yet. Thats just how good the vanilla game is that i haven't even remotely felt the need to go out and get mods for this game.

131293821.review:
[h1]This game is worth every cent.[/h1] 
Even every cent of that $5 increase that people are moaning about.

I've got 323 hours on record as of this review. If you like games with excellent QoL features, easy mod support, multiplayer that's quick and easy to set up, and countless hours of replayability, then Factorio should be on your list. It runs beautifully, even on low end hardware, because of excellent optimization done by these developers. 

If you like the idea of creating a factory and optimizing the logistical systems within, then this game is for you. If you like waging an environmental war using pollution to drive the natives into killing themselves on your walls, then this game is for you. If you like trains, this game is for you. There are lots of reasons to like the game. It's well made, better than most. If any of this sounds appealing to you, do yourself a favor and grab this game.

Unless you don't like the idea of spending all night playing because you're too immersed in the game to stop, I guess. Then you probably should stay away for your own health and safety.


[h1] Regarding the price increase Complaints [/h1]

Most products in the world go up in price over time due to inflation...it's actually somewhat strange that games sort of don't. Things tend to be priced at what people are willing to pay; here we see a dev treating their game as a product, and pricing accordingly. People are still buying it despite it not being on sale, so a sale is clearly not needed to get people playing it. It's [i]still[/i] selling well 7 years later? I know it's tough to swallow, but maybe that means its underpriced. If you bought in while it was undervalued, you're lucky. If not, you're just paying what it's worth.

Additionally, lots of games increase their price. There are lots of reasons for this, whether it's leaving early access, adding substantial amounts of content since launch, or to account for expansions that have been wrapped into the original game after they've been out for ages: World of Warcraft is a good example of this. 

The oddest part here about the complaints is that the people complaining are, almost by definition, customers who are in no way affected by the price increase. It's petty, childish, and shows a lack of understanding of economics to complain so bitterly as to join a review bomb about it. A sale is used to lower the price temporarily in order to [i]sell the game[/i] when the normal price isn't moving the volume of transactions you're hoping for. Factorio has seen remarkably consistent good sales volume, so why would they put it on sale? It's entitled to think that a developer should put a game on sale simply because there are people who haven't played the game yet. By that logic, developers should all just give their games away for free so everybody could play them.

[h1] TLDR: Game good, worth the (new) price, ignore the review bomb bumpkins who disable comments on their reviews [/h1]

134642204.review:
Ah, Factorio! It's a game that's a cross between a logistics simulator and a Rube Goldberg machine. If you're looking for a game that will test your engineering and problem-solving skills, then look no further.

Now, let's talk about the landscape. It's like the game's developers were trying to make you feel depressed with the environment. It's a bleak wasteland of pollution and destruction, but somehow, it's all so beautiful in its own weird way. The world of Factorio is a place where you can let your inner mad scientist run wild.

The gameplay is addictive and satisfying. The sheer number of things you can build and automate is staggering. You start with nothing, but before you know it, you're managing a massive factory, producing goods to sell, and defending yourself against hordes of aliens.

And don't even get me started on the soundtrack. It's like the developers took inspiration from a 1980s sci-fi movie and cranked it up to 11. The music is catchy and upbeat, making you feel like you're in the middle of an epic adventure.

Factorio is the kind of game that will suck you in for hours on end. You'll lose track of time as you optimize your production lines and defend against alien attacks. But even with all the challenges the game throws at you, you'll never feel overwhelmed.

So if you're looking for a game that will keep you entertained for hours on end, Factorio is the game for you. Just be prepared for the depression-inducing environment, but hey, maybe that's what makes the game so addictive.

130175719.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you Factorio

142079200.review:
[h1]The Game which created the genre[/h1]
[hr][/hr][i]Developers have an accord with the community that game will never go on sale. Having a small discount when buying in bundle with an expansions is fine, but if game ever goes on sale, this review will become negative.[/i][hr][/hr]
[h1]🔥The Jist of It🔥[/h1]

Factorio is one of those games which will remain classic to most people. It is a game which filled a niche and created a genre upon itself. It is a standard to which other factory style games can be compared to.

Game is like Minecraft. It is devoid of purpose. You must set them yourself if you want to enjoy playing it and it would be better be along the lines: "factory must grow" or else you might end up disappointed. You can sure try to launch the rocket and be satisfied by it. However, if you will not have goals or desire to try something new, game will eventually feel empty. It does not have enough polish or dynamic content to make you engaged any more than a playthrough and it relies heavily on modders keeping you entertained. 

[h1]🌈Never Ending Freebies🌈[/h1]
Game is designed around producing as much stuff as possible. Producing stuff for the sake of producing more stuff. 
[list]
[b][i]Power Generation[/i][/b]
[*]One of the areas where this is apparent is power generation. In this game, it is simplified to the point of absurdity. Only coal power is somewhat balanced method. Solar panels are pollution free and even generate electricity at night. However, for mega factories you need nuclear power. Nuclear power at first seems to require a lot of uranium ore, however there is Kovarex enrichment process which converts all of your excessive U-238 to useful U-235. However, that is not how enrichment process works at all. This process defies laws of thermodynamics and produces more energy from a closed system than you inputted. This results in you producing an infinite amount of electricity without needed to worry about running out of fuel. Since nuclear power produces a ton of electricity and fuel for it is practically infinite, a player does not need to consider electrical management in its Factory design. Factories as a result tend to be grossly inefficient and it is designed that way to crank as big of the numbers as possible.

[b][i]Modules & Beacons[/i][/b]
[*]I never liked modules, because they demand you to rethink how you design your base from what game just taught you. Then they introduce arcade-like stackable bonuses like -50% electricity consumption which somehow directly relates to pollution. Then you get speed modules which can add up to 150% speed and combine that with 50% extra speed. You do get ridiculous performance gains. This can be used as a lazy excuse not to design a better factory, because you can just make it magically far better or it can be used to inflate production at a whim instead of building more lines or just using lower end assemblers. They also trivialise things like pollution management in this game. This mechanic breaks a lot of systems in this game and it is done to inflate players production quotas and to allow them to control production/pollution speed with a switch of a button. This raises a question for me. Why you can't just design a factory to do such a thing? Isn't designing a factory the whole point in Factorio? As it happens, no it is not. Factory must grow, as they say. The whole point of this game are big numbers as you produce stuff for stuff's sake.

[b][i]Conveyor Belts[/i][/b]
[*]Conveyor belts are another affront to God. It defies natural order of things and is an infinite energy generator. You do not need to fuel it or to maintain it. It is a perfect solution to solve all your logistics needs for free. This had stuck with me, because I remember playing Settlers 2 and how much fun I had in that game managing roads and logistics of my workers going to the various production buildings and bringing back goods. Logistics of an economy game was always the part which I enjoyed the most. This part is greatly simplified in Factorio. Instead you have a perfect line which delivers goods anywhere you want to quite extreme speeds. Massive speed of Express Belts allows players to fully saturate a single belt without having to think amount multi-belt approach due to bandwidth limitations. 

[b][i]Drones[/i][/b]
[*]These little fellows actually surprised me, because they are fun to use and ability to construct factories from blueprints on global map is actually a very useful feature as it is an auto repair. However, that is just another example how logistics is overly simplified in this game. Drones allow you to transport anything anywhere without a need to worry about physical connections. They essentially nullify need for logistics for anything, but most volume intensive tasks. Since electricity is essentially free in this game, drones also become a free tool to use.
[/list]
[h1]☢️Community☢️[/h1]
Games like this often attract people with deep personal issues who use games as an escape mechanism. Such people often make everyone else as miserable as they are. I tried to share my experience in Steam forum, but it is an open battleground. People can't accept that a person might have something negative to say. They do not understand what an opinion is. They try to argue against an opinion and to prove that your opinion is wrong and their opinion is right. They pretend to talk in place of developers and create toxic, unwelcoming place where you must either fall into the party lines of "FACTORY MUST GROW AT ALL COSTS" or get ready for constant harassment and questioning. These people will contest literally everything you say. Will scream how wrong you are at everything and then immediately drop the conversation in the middle of discussion and never talk about it again.

However, I kept pushing through not for them, but for my right to use public places to express my own experiences. I'm sharing more detailed version of them here:
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Calicifer/discussions/0/3824158244554053005/

If you want to see what a mess this community is, you can go to watch circus here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/427520/discussions/0/3826410044369061413/?tscn=1689276285

I made a video which goes into more details to some issues which I had in this game. Mind you, not all of them are bugs.
https://youtu.be/ITaeXU8L9OQ

[h1]📋An Exhaustive Conclusion📋[/h1]
Factorio is a long game. It is a giant time commitment. It was fun at times, bothersome at other moments and plain boring in the end. It front loads its difficulty at player at the start and then proceeds to simplify all the processes after mid game. However, mid game was where I had most fun in trying to figure out and do something unique. After that, it was about redesigning my base over and over again to meet ever increasing production demands. Then it was about constantly doing mundane stuff and connecting more base materials supply. In the end, I achieved sustainable production which allowed me to fully complete the game. It felt empty and hollow as it overstayed its welcome. It drags everything mercilessly. You get unreasonably high requirements of everything and thus you have to spend a lot of time growing your factory. It constantly shifts what you need, from where you need it and how much you need it. This drags out gameplay and complicates it to players which causes high drop out rates even among veterans who tried main campaign many times, but dropped it. Fully completing vanilla experience is a chore. Then you do it, it just feels empty as game has nothing else to offer.

143381936.review:
Factorio is hands down the most captivating factory-building game I've ever played. From the moment I fired it up, I knew I was in for a treat. This game is a masterpiece of engineering and management, delivering an addictive blend of resource gathering, automation, and problem-solving that keeps me glued to my screen for hours on end.

The learning curve might be a bit steep, but the feeling of accomplishment when you optimize your production lines and witness your factory humming with efficiency is incomparable. Every challenge is an opportunity to refine and expand, always pushing you to think a step ahead. It's an endless puzzle, and I love it!

The game's graphics may not be cutting-edge, but they exude a charming retro vibe that grows on you. The sound design is simple yet effective, complementing the gameplay perfectly without ever being intrusive. The modding community adds even more value, introducing new features, scenarios, and quality-of-life improvements.

One of the aspects that truly sets Factorio apart is its cooperative multiplayer. Teaming up with friends to tackle ambitious projects and fend off the relentless biters makes for unforgettable gaming sessions. The collaborative element brings a whole new dimension to the game, and you'll find yourself hooked for countless cooperative adventures.

The developers deserve immense praise for their ongoing dedication to improving and expanding the game. Frequent updates and engaging communication with the community showcase their passion for the project.

However, I must warn you: Factorio is highly addictive. Once you start building your factories and optimizing your production chains, time loses its meaning. "Just one more automation tweak" quickly turns into a marathon gaming session. Prepare to sacrifice sleep, for Factorio's allure is irresistible.

In conclusion, Factorio is a must-play for any fan of strategy, management, or engineering games. It's a delightfully addictive experience that rewards creativity and problem-solving in equal measure. Factorio's replayability and endless possibilities ensure that it will remain a staple in my gaming library for years to come.

136937618.review:
I thought I'd seen it all. Then I encountered the maddeningly addictive, soul-snatching world of Factorio by the devious masterminds at Wube Software. With just 11 hours of playtime, I was already a lost cause, my soul firmly in the game's clutches as I obsessively tinkered with conveyor belts, robotic arms, and fended off feisty extraterrestrial menaces.

Factorio's gameplay is like a sweetly crooning siren, beckoning players into a labyrinth of production lines and resource management so intense it makes your head spin. The seemingly innocent graphics soon reveal their true nature as your sprawling, chaotic industrial empire comes to life before your very eyes. It's as if the game murmurs, "Surrender, mortal. Your soul is mine!" And let's be honest, who wouldn't succumb to such a tantalizingly treacherous temptation?

Amidst the mind-boggling complexity of managing an ever-growing factory, the developers somehow found the perfect way to inject humor into the mix. Quirky pop culture references, sly puns, and subtle jabs at your own sanity are cleverly woven into the game, leaving you chuckling maniacally as your factory spirals into a frenzy of mayhem and automation.

The pièce de résistance, however, is the multiplayer mode, where you can team up with (or battle against) friends and strangers, sharing both the joys and woes of interstellar conquest. Is there anything more hilarious than watching your buddy accidentally launch a rocket at their own factory? I think not!

With its devilishly addictive gameplay, cunningly deceptive graphics, and irresistible wit, Factorio is an absolute must-play for gamers craving a challenge that transcends the ordinary. So, what are you waiting for? Strap on your hard hat, join the riotous rollercoaster of factory madness, and embrace the soul-stealing hilarity that is Factorio!

124267542.review:
My friend mentioned this game a few years ago and I thought it sounded pretty boring. I hadn't seen any images or videos of it before playing. Every time he brought it up, I thought, "how could building a factory be fun?" "What's the point?" 

September 2022, he decides to gift me the game as a birthday gift. I played for the first time, having no prior knowledge and not even doing the tutorial. It was definitely not bad. 

A few hours later, I was learning but it was still just good to me. However, a month later, I played the game again on my own, to get the achievements because I like getting all achievements in games. This was when it clicked. I looked at the clock, it was 9 am. I looked at it again, it was 3 pm. The next time I looked, it was nearly 9 pm. I had been hooked. It was a strange feeling. I hadn't felt this way about a game in a long time. The last time I felt time passing by as quick was with Civilization 6. Yes, I have been addicted to games before and played them all day, like Minecraft or Don't Starve Together, but they never made me forget about the time. Five minutes in Factorio seems to turn into 5 hours real quick. I, then, understood the hype and how addictive it was. 

128 hours later, I have gotten all achievements. And now, I taut this as being one of the greatest games of all time. I needn't spend 1,000 hours in this game to know its worth and value, because how it made me feel--how it makes the player feel--is certainly incredible.

146823643.review: I sat down and played the demo for five minutes that turned into 70 that turned into buying the game that turned into four hours... I'm not sure I can put it down yet.

146819310.review:
About time I wrote a review! I would recommend this game to literally anyone, but it definitely lives in a niche. I find great mental peace being able to build factories at the grand scale made possible by Factorio, but still being given the tools for spaghettifying it all. Sure, there are other factory games, but this one is mine and I think it's the best. 
The team at Wube has kept this game moving forward akin to the loyalty of Terraria and the announced Space Exploration expansion has come with news of sweeping Quality-of-Life changes that get my neurons buzzing.

132429210.review:
For the people who don't understand the price increase:

Due to economic inflation, the company who made Factorio decided to leverage this as justification to increase the price of the game. 

This was not the actual reason for the price increase, however. The real reason was to make the playerbase angry. There is a name for this in economics: Fury Inflation, and it has been proven in multiple studies that games which employ this tactic attract more sales. 

According to Edwin, increasing the price adds to the "R" factor. The higher the R factor the more sales a product attracts. I strongly encourage you to look up Fury Inflation to learn more as there are many real world examples and you can avoid falling into this trap as well.

130319155.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

22390398.review:
I started a co-op factory with a close friend. After a day of work, I stepped back, looked at what we built, and came to some realizations.

1) I have no fucking idea whats going on in this factory
2) Half the components that directly interact with each other aren't even near one another, one of the machines producing copper cable for another machine to assemble into circuit boards is halfway across the god damn refinery
3) 90% of the conveyor belts are underground, and the rest are going so many directions this thing looks like a ball of yarn
4) There is coal fucking EVERYWHERE
5) I maintain enough sanity to count to 5
6) Staring at this thing makes my eyes itch
7) Looking away makes my brain itch

The scariest part is that it keeps getting bigger, and every time it gets bigger it somehow becomes MORE labrynthine. One of those fucking conveyor belts goes all the way around the entire factory to deliver steel plates to a single assembler thats making bloody gears, and its right next to the refinery itself!

Sometimes the factory breaks. We don't usually notice because of how much of a mess this thing is, and the breaks we do spot are often half an hour old and are a recurring problem. Rather than fix it, we simply unjam the machine and ignore it until it breaks again. The biggest problem to fixing it comes from our production lines. Normal production lines look like a grid. Ours looks like you threw a bunch of squares into a bowl of spaghetti noodles and gave the bowl to a five year old for a period of one to five minutes. This proccess results in either an empty bowl and a full five year old, a floor covered in noodles, or spaghetti all over the walls and ceiling with the squares nowhere to be found. Knowing the trend in increasing chaos and complexity the factory exhibits, probably all three.

The factory is an empodiment of madness incomprehensible even to the men who built it, laid every unholy circuit of conveyor belt, a thousand arms madly spinning every second, countless plates of copper and iron in a complex dance the likes of which is unseen in the realm of mere mortals. There are sections that I have no idea how they work, and I BUILT THEM.

The factory grows more complex with each passing second and more convoluted every milisecond. Perhaps the reason is in part due to each segment being constructed with no plans for future additions, then the future additions were constructed by forcibly adapting the existing segments, usually by shoving more tubes into it rather than actually redesigning it, and these futrue additions are also not planned for expansion. The end result is a cluster-fuck so large in magnitude, the last time a cluster-fuck rivaled it in size, God smote the town and turned its inhabitants into salt. Unfortunately no god can save us from this... thing.

Having expanded it further its almost as if the factory has a mind of its own, an ever hungry consciousness burning with dark malevolence and the need to grow. It infects all who stand in its presence, compelling them to add to it. A hundred furnaces belch smoke and the black blood of the earth is torn from its cradle to fuel the fires of industry. The ecosystem is demolished and the skin of the planet is rent and shattered for its glittering treasures, tossed into the inferno of a thousand stone and metal prisons to be transformed, used to expand the malignant blight upon the world that we brought. Ten thousand steel cogs turn and steam fills the air as the never ending fires boil the oceans away to power the sprawling spiderweb of mechanised mayhem, ordered chaos at its purest, a hundred thousand plates of steel and copper cycle and swirl in patterns barely knowable by the very people that created them.

Each day, the red and green fluids are pumped into glowing crystalline globes, each sparking and burning, discovering new knowledge and new machines. The factory grows. Each advance in technology only complicates matters. The factory grows. The new advances create a need for new resources. The factory grows. The new resources require new means of transportation. The factory grows. The new transportation feeds new machines that burn the new resources to produce blue fluids to discover new technology. The factory grows. The blue fluids feed the globes to reveal new truths, beginning the vicious cycle anew, a neverending circle of destruction and growth that will only end when every corner of the planet is scoured clean. The factory grows. The planet will never be scoured clean. The factory grows. The planet is infinite in size. The factory grows. The game will never be over.

The factory grows.



Epilogue:

//: Date: 6/21/[ERROR_NULL_VALUE]

Resources have dried up again. The factory consumes all within its reach, insatiable in its hunger. Though it had experienced full production stoppages in the past, the factory could never be eliminated from the planet by the natives, for the sun itself powered the beams of destruction that maintained its borders. Within the creaking, ancient cogs and permanent haze of foul and polluted smoke, a single humanoid shape slowly rises to its feet. Aged, failing flesh and bone long ago replaced with steel and chrome, once polished and clean, now weathered by uncountable years of exposure to acid rain and blackened by thick, choking smog, form its excuse for a body. It could have left while it was still human, before it was consumed in body by the foundry it created to escape. It never had a chance to leave, mind and soul devoured in the pursuit of freedom. With slow, clanking steps and the steady drip of oil from its joints, like a bleeding mechanical nightmare brought to hideous life, it stands and rasps as it moves for the exit. Behind it, a thousand drones rise like a plague of locusts, ready to continue the endless harvest. As the abomination that was once a man steps towards the gates of the factory, a mighty space faring vessel lies decrepit in its dry dock deep within the core of the facility. It was supposed to be a way off the planet, the whole reason for the factory's construction. But soon, the building of the factory became the means and the end, no thought other than the constant urge to grow in its mind.

The only machine resembling the human form in the entire world stepped out into the barren wasteland of the ruined world. A keening, howling wind tears across the surface, forests destroyed by the ruined atmosphere no longer keeping it in check.

It is the cry of a dead world, echoing forever on a planet overtaken by the machine.

31108986.review:
Help for new players.

Rule #1. When you think you have enough iron, you don't. Trust me.
Rule #2. When you have backups in your system, don't worry, you'll have shortages later. Get more iron.
Rule #3. Leave enough room to expand without having to do crazy stuff with your belts. Spaghetti is fun, until it isn't because you can't send enough material down the entire belt, and there's no room to supplement it down the line.
Rule #4. When you have backups, start storing extras in chests. You'll need it later.
Rule #5. Crap, I'm out of copper. Get more copper.
Rule #6. Create dedicated factory towns for iron plates and copper plates, and build gear wheels and copper cables on site. It's much more efficient than trying to transport them.
Rule #6. Wait, there is automation for automation? Flying robots? Check.
Rule #7. Aliens love radars. Don't put radars near things that matter (like your steam engines) unless you support them with enough turrets.
Rule #7-a. Flamethrowers are your friend for killing aliens. Unless you're in the middle of your town, in which case they are not.
Rule #7-b. Same goes with atomic weapons. When you're not actively fighting outside your base, remove atomic bombs from your hotbar unless you want a very expensive mistake (read: hole) in your factory.
Rule #8. Take enough ammo with you when you go to fight aliens. It's lots of fun to run out of ammo in the middle of a battle, and it goes quickly.
Rule #8-b. Personal laser turrets are a gigantic step forward in biter-fighting - just ensure you have enough power to keep them going.
Rule #9. Don't stand on train tracks when trains are automated.
Rule #10. Use the little overlay in map view to see where your power poles are. Create redundancies so an entire section of your base is not dependent on a single pole somewhere (you will accidentally destroy or remove it at some point, guaranteed - ahem, cars).
Rule #11. Blueprints are amazing, and the community is fantastic at sharing their different creations. Try them out, and then see if you have a better or more creative way to make something work (if you want).
Rule #12. Deconstruction planning forests is amazing. Clear out wood quickly, or filter to only pick up certain types of items (e.g. items laying on the ground, or just small power poles).
Rule #13. Logistics robots change your world.
Rule #13-a. You always need more power.
Rule #14. The modding community is active and makes lots of ways to keep the game fresh.
Rule #15. Oh, there's a better way to build that. Let me start over. Again.
Rule #16. Wait, is that the sun coming up already?
Rule #17. Remember your family fondly.
Rule #18 Get more iron.

Cracktorio is more accurate.

10/10

73552679.review:
This game is extremely addictive for one simple reason: it's a sandbox survival game with zero grind, because everything can be automated.

In a normal survival game, to craft 100 items, you need to first harvest 100 of some resource. In this game, you set up a power plant, a coal mine to fuel the it, an iron mine, a few assembly plants, a few conveyor belts and a chest and then wait for it to fill up with 100 grenades while you go work on another part of the factory. Meanwhile, the increasing pollution makes the bugs native to the planet increasingly agitated.

Automation is extended into every single part of the gameplay - you can mass produce buildings, then use robots to place them according to blueprints, transport items with automatic trains, and create complex control networks to let production adapt to demand. There is always something to do with very little repetition - a sudden bug attack, a bottleneck in your iron production, a depleted ore patch that forces you to explore for a new one. People spend absurd amounts of time on this game because it doesn't waste any of it.

39568755.review:
Coming up to 5000 hours playing this game, and im still learning new things in multiplayer.  

The devs are by far the best ive ever seen.  FFF (Friday Fun Facts) is a blog post they write up every Friday.  Every. Single. Friday. For the last ... 4 years?  look at them on their website, its not a 2 min blurb, its a full review of what they've done that week, and where they're headed, what their plans are, current iterations they're going over, complete with pictures and sometimes *chuckle* hand drawn graphs.  

Their IRC channel (there is a link on their website) has someone on the dev team there pretty much 24/7.  Not just "community manager" nitwits (Trangar, te he), but guys like Rseding91 (their C++ guru) that are programming the actual updates.  

Oh.  There are updates.

Are there sometimes bugs in the patches?  Sure.  Which is why you sometimes see 2 patches in the same day.  Bugs get quashed immediately whenever possible.  

While this review doesnt speak much about the game, the team behind it deserves the recognition - its amazing, thoughtul, and incredibly well done because of them.

In a nutshell, its similar to RTS games like starcraft, where you build up and gather resources.  But instead of spending 20 minutes to build up a base to have the game end in 2, you keep building.

Building Bigger.

Making things more efficient.

Tearing down and rebuidling.

Im almost 5000 hours in and sticking with vanilla until I can personally say Ive mastered it.  Once I stop learning new things almost every time I play, ill start fooling around with mods.  And there are lots of them.  

Is this game worth $20?  It absolutely was for me.  This single $20 purchase brought me thousands of hours of entertaintment, frustration - when things didnt work planned, and absolute delight - when things get fixed, and I can reflect on my orchestra of 500 machines working in harmony.  

Whether or not it is worth it for you is up to you.  But I would be remiss if i didnt impore you to give it a try, get the demo, fool around, commit an hour or two.

If you have the money, and like using your brain to overcome problems and build things, BUY THIS GAME!

The good
-Great for unlimited play. There is always more to do.
-Multiplayer is super fun, and much less laggy then anticipated.
-The enemy progression system is near perfect
-Runs very well, even with over 300 robots all doing different things on the screen.
-Very customisable world
-Very smooth controls
-The combat robots are awesome
-Modules and suit upgrades out the wazoo
-The logic systems and rail systems are very polished and well done
-Most early access games I have played, I have found many bugs. I have not found a single bug in this game.
-The blueprint system is easy, efficiant, and well done.
-Robots are very polished and do what they're supposed to very well.
-Devs are awesome!
-Best builder/tower defence game I have ever played


Could use some work
-Vehicles are a little sub par, but still fun to use
-Armor augmentatin system is a little broken. I should not be able to run faster then a train, or take on a max level enemy base with a shotgun
-Inserter speed is limited for extreme late game. I found myself needing 2 or 3 fast inserters just to load enough copper into one assembler for wire
-lack of enemy types
-Water and lake boundries, and some way to clear them or build over them.
-not many methods of producing power

The Bad (most being fixed in updates coming soon most likely)
-A lack of end game. Once the rocket is launched, you have nothing else to progress too, aside from expanding your current base. 
-Weapons. There are 6 weapons in the game, 3 are shit and one is god tier, will most likely be balanced soon.

Things I would personally like to see/Pipe dreams
-A gamemode or checkbox of "Extreme survival" requiring you to eat, drink, and sleep through nights. Enemies may have more advanced AI in this gamemode.
-Space. Although this is a little far fetched, add the ability to set up a space station, mine astroids or even moons. Or even travel to a different planet all together. Including a sort of out of atmosphere solar panel, which was what I thought the satalite was going to do.
-More biomes. Some biomes containing different enemy types, or some having extreme tempatures that require a suit module to survive in, but also much richer in resources
-More power production methods! Nuclear power for examble.
-A sort of "Deep mining" drill. A drill that extracts ore from deep underground, in a much slower, power consuming fassion. This could also be a good way to get end game ore.
-End game ore. Uranium, Diamond, Platinum. 
-An enemy "Hive Mind". Sort of like the worms that spawn, only huge. Controlls the underlings, and directs them. Destroy hive mind, end all sort of alien attacks in that biome. Destroying the hive mind would need to be extreamly difficult.
-Air vehices. I would love to be able to quickly get around the base or area without worrying about hitting a pipe or electrical pole. Also including a "Sky transport", like a end game train that does not need tracks.
-Differenty types of miners, more suitable and productive for late game.
-The ability to grow trees and cut them down, and produce charchoal from the wood, leading to a renewable source of coal.
-Crops, either to eat and regain health, or to use as bio-fuel. 
-More and more exotic types of weapons. We have the alien artifacts, why not use them to make an acid launcher or a plasma beam?
-More natual fluids aside from water. Have a rarer type of volcanic biome that produces lava, which can be used to power thermal generators.
-More enemies! More powerfull versions of the origional enemies. A type of behomoth biter multiplied by 5. Flying enemies, subterainian enemies, water based enemies, enemy base levels, producing higher level enemies and giving more artifacts when destroyed.
-Some drop from basic enemies. Chitin used for armor, Meat used to cook, Spitter acid as an alternate use to make batteries or poison bullets, worm teeth for drill augmentations, the list goes on.
-Robot companions. Robots that help you with things other then fighting for 120 secconds or building stuff.
-Neutral mosters. Things like wild space animals that don't want to kill you. Possibly tamable and kept as a pet or something
-More train types! Trains requiring advanced fuel, or even magnetic trains that travel hundreds of miles an hour.
-Teleporters(?) requring disgusting amounts of power, but able to transfer anything, including items, over great distances instantly. Cound even include coming from space or an astroid to the home world, requiring some sort of airlock.
-Pressure chambers! Pressurising air to make types of materials, like alloys or more compressed liquids.
-Steam workshop support! There are a lot of great mods out there, and the steam workshop just makes them accessed easier.
-PvP or factions maybe?
-Proximity voice chat?

Simply put, I love this game. I have never even heard of these devs until now, and they are some of the best devs I have seen. If you like builders, tower defence games, survival games, or anything like those genres, buy this game. I already know you will love it.
